Yes—I recollect a shawl that I sold her—she paid me for it—I have had no quarrel with her—she has not refused to do work that I have wished her to do—she has nothing to do with my washing—I put it out—she has sometimes washed a few trifles—she had left the room about twenty minutes when I opened her box—I did not tell her I was going to do it—it had no lock—the calico was the shawl I had sold her—it was folded up, and the edge of the calico was outside—I have sold her things, but she never bought such a thing as this jean in the shop in her life of me—Mr. and Mrs. Davy, the apprentice, and me, are engaged in the shop—the prisoner spent most of her wages in buying things—all the people in that house have a ready access to that room, and her box was always open—my master's shop was in confusion—the things were all about—to the best of

my knowledge the prisoner removed the things that were, moved to the next house—we do not cut out the private marks when we sell goods—if a per
son was to take the whole length, they would have the mark.

HENRY VERNON PARKER (police-sergeant K 5.) I went with Mr. Davy, and took the things out of the box—I heard the prisoner say to her mother, that she did not take the piece of black silk, but she took the jean and the calico—she said something to the Magistrate—I did not notice its being taken down.
Cross-examined. Q. Was this conversation taken down at the office? A. No, I did not mention it to the Magistrate—this is the first time I have mentioned it.
NOT GUILTY .

1653.
MARGARET WILTSHIRE and
MARY SHEA were indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of May, 1 purse, value 1s.; 1 seal, 3s.; and 4 half-crowns: the goods of
William Kay, from his person.

WILLIAM KAY . I am a private in the first batallion of Grenadier Guards. I was at the Forresters' Arms on Saturday the 6th of May, between three and four o'clock in the afternoon—Wiltshire came in and asked me if her hus
band was in the hospital—I had seen her before, and knew the person whom she described—I said I believed he was—Shea then came in—Wiltshire spoke to her, and I gave her some beer—Wiltshire then went away, and came back—I staid there till six—I then went away with the two prisoners and another woman—while I was going down Gloucester-place, talking to Wilt
shire, I felt my right hand coat-skirt fall—Shea was walking close behind me—I put my hand into my pocket, and missed my purse and four half-crowns, and a small metal seal—Wiltshire was at that time close to me, and had hold of my arm—Shea was about a pace in the rear of me—when I turned I ac
cused Shea of taking my purse—she said she had not, and she ran away—I caught her, and took her to the Sovereign, in Park-row—I found Wiltshire there—I saw Wiltshire throw my purse on the ground—it had my seal still in it, but no money.

Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. The prisoners are sisters, are they not? A. I do not know—I do not know that Wiltshire is married to a com
rade of mine—the one she describes as her husband is in the hospital—Margaret Burke was in the public-house with me—I am in confinement in the barracks for being absent—I was a lance-corporal, and am now reduced to a private—I was at the beer-shop with Wiltshire and Burke about half-past three, and Shea came in a little after—Shea said she had come to fetch her sister—Wiltshire asked her to stop, and we continued drinking—about four o'clock Shea's mother came—I did not ask her to drink—she went away, leaving the prisoners there—when I went out I did not ask the prisoners to go with me—when I went into the first public-house, I had about 17s., and when I left it I had about 9s., besides the four half-crowns—the silver was in my left-hand coat pocket—I had not taken my purse out at all—I did not say when the purse was thrown down, that it was of no use without the money—I was quite sober—I am quite certain that the purse was not in my hands, and the hands of the prisoners while I was in the public-house—Wiltshire did not appear to be tipsy—I did not make her drunk—we did not drink three pints-altogether—she might have been the worse for liquor—she did not say in the public-house that she would take care of the money, and pay for any more liquor that came in—she never saw the money I had—I did not say I would spend it in drink.
COURT. Q. Are you sure you had your purse and that four half-crowns in it when you left the house? A. Yes.

WILLIAM MOUDLER . I am groom to Mr. Gray, in St. John's-wood-road, I was in Park-row—I saw the prosecutor running after Shea and Burke—he took them into the Sovereign—I followed them, and saw Shea pass a purse to Wiltshire in the tap-room, and saw Wiltshire throw the purse down—the prosecutor picked it up—the officer was sent for, and took the prisoner.
ELIZABETH SPREADBOROUGH . I am the wife of a policeman—I live at the station-house in Harcourt-street—Wiltshire was brought there—I found two half-crowns in her pocket, and one fell down.

THOMAS SHAW (police-constable D 112.) The prisoners were given into my custody on that Saturday evening—I received this purse from the pro
secutor—I told the prisoners what they were charged with, and they denied it.

WILLIAM KAY
re-examined. This is my purse and this seal was in it.
NOT GUILTY .

1654.
MARY ANN BROADER was indicted
for stealing, on the 26th of April, 1 watch, value 2l. 10s., the goods of
George Long, from his person.

GEORGE LONG . I am a gardener, and live in Ashton-street, Poplar. On the 27th of April, about twelve o'clock at night, I was at the Harrow public-house—the prisoner came in when I was going to give another girl some gin—the girl who was with me gave the prisoner some gin—the prisoner was quite close to me—I took my watch out merely to see what time it was—it was a double case silver watch—I held it in my hand, and the prisoner took it out—I was sober, and I believe she was sober—I asked her to give it up, and another girl came in and wanted her to give it up—she said she would not—the other girl fell on her—I pulled the other girl off, and the prisoner ran away with my watch—I ran after her, but did not overtake her—this is it.

Cross-examined by Mr. HORRY. Q. Is it true that you were drinking all day with Ellen Palmer? A. No—I met with her in the evening—I might have been an hour with her before the prisoner came in and joined us—I prevented Palmer from stopping the prisoner—I thought I could take away the watch from her myself—I did not know the prisoner before.

JOHN KEMPSON (police-sergeant K 25.) About two o'clock in the morn
ing, on the 27th of April, in consequence of something I heard from the prosecutor, I went to No. 2, Red Lion-court—I found the prisoner in bed with a girl named Neale—I told the prisoner I should take her for taking the prosecutor's watch at the Harrow—she said, "I am not dozey Poll"—(which is a name she goes by)—the other girl said, "I am dozey Poll"—I took them both to the station-house—the prisoner first said she knew nothing about the watch, but at the station, she said she took it, but there was a scuffle, and she dropped it, and did not know what became of it.

HENRY WOOD (police-constable K 44.) I went to No. 2, Red Lion-court—I went into the garden, and found the earth had been turned up fresh at the foot of a currant-bush—I turned it up about six inches, and found this watch.

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined Six Months.

p.hi: Fifth Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

div1.p:
1655.
MARY ANN WILLIAMS and
ELIZA DARVILL
were indicted for stealing, on the 30th of April, 1 watch, value 4l.; 1 watch-chain, 30s.; 1 seal, 1l.; and 1 watch-key, 8s. 6d.; the goods of
John Niblett.

JOHN NIBLETT . I am a porter, and live in George-court, Strand. On the 30th of April, about twelve or one o'clock at night, I met the prisoner Wil
liams in Long-acre—I went with her to King-street, Drury-lane—Darvill was in the room—I sent out for some gin and beer—I stopped some time—Darvill went and laid down, and then Williams followed her—I then laid down and went to sleep—I had put my watch on the table—after a short time I awoke—Darvill and my watch were then gone—Williams was in bed with me—I went to an officer—my watch was found—this is it.
Cross-examined by MR. WYLDE. Q. Were there other people in the house? A. Yes, there are others living in the house—I do not think there was any lock on the door—I never was there before.
JAMES BROWN (police-constable F 142.) I took Williams in Drury-lane—this watch was found on her.
HANNAH ROWELL. I searched Williams on the 1st of May, and found this silver watch, and seal and key on her.

WILLIAMS—
GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Confined Three Months.

DARVILL—
NOT GUILTY .

1656.
GEORGE JONES was indicted
for stealing, on the 10th of May, 1 pair of trowsers, value 7s., the goods of
John Madden.

JOHN MADDEN . I keep a shop in Well-street, Oxford-street. I missed a pair of trowsers on the 10th of May, about seven o'clock—I saw the prisoner that day, and taxed him with having them—he denied it—they are mine.
JOHN BRIGGONS . I saw the prisoner take the trowsers from the side of the prosecutor's door.
ROBERT ADAMS (police-constable E 109.) I found these trowsers in a place where the prisoner was standing—I saw him drop them.

GUILTY . Aged 14.—
Confined Three Months.—The first and last Week Solitary.

1657.
JOSEPH POOLE was indicted
for stealing, on the 7th of May, 2 half-crowns, 3 shillings, and 2 sixpences, and 1 groat, the monies of
Joseph Hilton.

JOSEPH HILTON . I live in Gibraltar-walk, Bethnal-green—the prisoner slept with me for a week—I went to bed on Saturday night, the 29th of April, at twelve o'clock, and was awoke by some one knocking at the door, and Mr. Mullins let the prisoner in—he came to bed—I awoke again very early, and, heard the church clock strike four—the prisoner got up in bed, and was pulling my trowsers over the bed—I asked what he wanted, he said he was cold—he pulled them up towards the head, and laid down—in a few minutes he got up again—I saw him dressing, and when he was going down he pitched my trowsers on the wall side—I had had two half-crowns, three shillings, two sixpences, and a fourpenny-piece in them, and when I got up, my money was gone—when he pulled my trowsers across the bed I heard the silver rattle in them.
Prisoner. Q. What did you say when I got up? A. I asked what you wanted.
FRANCIS WHITE . I took the prisoner on the Monday afternoon—I found 5s. 8d. on him.

Prisoner's Defence. I was passing by the door where the prosecutor lodges; I went in and got a lodging there, on the Saturday evening I received my money. I had got 6s. in my pocket; it was my jacket that I pulled over me, as it had rolled off; the prosecutor knows I was paid.

JOSEPH HILTON
re-examined, I do not know that he had any money of his own that night—he left about five o'clock in the morning.

GUILTY . *—
Transported for Seven Years.

1658.
CHARLES BRIGHTLY was indicted
for stealing, on the 10th of May, 1 brass cap, value 4d., the goods of
Edwin Douglas Worrill.

EDWIN DOUGLAS WORRILL . I live in Church-lane, Whitechapel. I am an engineer, and keep a shop in Cannon-street. I went to dinner last Wednes
day, and came back at two o'clock—I then missed this brass cap—sus
pecting the prisoner, I went to him and said, "Charles, have you taken the cap out of my shop? tell me what you have done with it; I don't want to hurt you"—I found this cap at Mrs. Tilley's—it is mine, JANE TILLEY. I am a marine-store dealer—I bought this cap of the pri
soner for 1d.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 12.—
Confined Eleven Days, and
Whipped.

1659.
JAMES HOMER was indicted
for stealing, on the 7th of May, 2 pieces of board, value 10d., and 5 pieces of wood, 1s. 6d.; the goods of
John Cloutman; and that he had been before convicted of felony.
JOHN CLOUTMAN . I am a carpenter, and live in Leonard-street—I missed two pieces of board and five pieces of wood, on Monday, the 8th of May—these are them.
JAMES CLARK (police-sergeant N 15.) I stopped the prisoner with these boards and wood, on Sunday, the 7th of May—he said be brought them from his uncle at Highbury.

ROBERT BISSBEACH . I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former convic
tion, which I got from the clerk of the peace for Surrey—(read)—I was the prosecutor in that case—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 16.—
Confined One Year.

1660.
SARAH WILLIAMS and
HANNAH WRIGHT were indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of May, 1 pair of boots, value 10s.; the goods of
Ri
chard Wallace Dare and another; and that Williams had been before convicted of felony; to which

WILLIAMS pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Confined Twelve Months.

HENRY WILSON . I am shopman to Richard Wallace Dare and another, of St. John-street-road. About half-past seven o'clock in the evening, on the 11th of May, the prisoners came in—Williams asked for a pair of boots—while I got them, I saw Wright reach something down from a shelf behind her, which she passed to Williams—I fitted the boots on to Williams, who paid for them; and they went out in a hurried manner—I went after them, and saw Williams take something from Wright, who then turned back—I gave her to a gentleman, and pursued Williams—I saw her throw these boots away—a lad took them up, and gave them to me—they are my master's.
THOMAS ONSLOW . I am a policeman. I saw Williams throw these boots away, and I stopped her.
Wright. I never touched them nor saw them.

WRIGHT—
GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Confined Four Months.

1661.
LOUISA JOHNSON and
SARAH WILLIAMS were indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of May, 1 bag, value 3d.; 4 sovereigns, 1 half-crown, 3 shillings, and 4 sixpences; the property of
Joseph Verander, from his person.
JOSEPH VERANDER . I live at Maldon, in Essex, and am a hardwareman—between twelve and one o'clock on the night of the 12th of May, I was in

Smithfield, and was accosted by Williams, who asked me to go home with her, which I refused—while I was talking with her, Johnson came up, and said, "Will you go home with me?"—I said no; I wanted to go to Long-lane—they said they would go with me—they both laid hold of me, one on each side—I tried to get away—Williams altered her position, and got a little in front—at that moment I felt a hand come out of my right
hand trowsers pocket, in which I had had a bag, with four sovereigns and the silver stated—they both had hold of me at that time, and I saw Williams pass something to Johnson—I then felt, and my bag was gone—I said I was robbed—they both declared I was not—I said, "I am sure I am, "and I saw my bag in Johnson's hand—Williams said, "Give the b----his bag; "which Johnson did; but I fancied I had been robbed—I still held them, and called the police—I saw Johnson put her hand to her mouth, and I heard something rattle in her mouth—I said, "She is swallowing something"—she said she was not—the policeman came and took her—I missed three sovereigns from the bag at the station.
Johnson. He asked us the way to Long-lane—I said I would show him—he gave both his arms to us, and told us to accept his arms. Witness. I did not; they came and seized me.
ESTHER WOOLLIDGE . I searched the prisoners—I found on Williams a sovereign, a 1s., and a 6d., and 2 1/2 d.—she said she had nothing but a 6d. about her.
Johnson's Defence. He said he had lost his bag—I took it off the ground and gave it him—I had a sovereign, and was afraid he would own it—that was why I said I had only a 6d.

JOHNSON—
GUILTY . Aged 36.—
Confined Six Months.

WILLIAMS—
GUILTY . Aged 26.—
Confined Three Months.

1662.
SUSAN JAMES was indicted
for stealing, on the 5th of May, 1 shawl, value 4d.; 1 box, 1s.; 1 pair of stockings, 1s. 6d.; 1 cap, 1s. 6d.; 2 pillow cases, 1s. 6d.; 3 towels, 4d.; and 2 table cloths, 6d.; the goods of
Elizabeth Sullivan.

ELIZABETH SULLIVAN . I live in Twine-court, Shad well. On the 5th of May the prisoner came out of the workhouse, and told me she had neither home nor habitation—I said if she could make shift with me and my boy, she might come—on Wednesday she went out, between eleven and twelve o'clock, and came back between seven and eight in the evening, with a man—I went to my next door neighbour for about ten minutes—when I came back, the man was still there; but I missed my box and a shawl which had been on it—on the Friday after I met her in the street, with my shawl on—I said, "For goodness' sake give me what was in the box, or acknowledge it; I won't hurt you"—she said she would not—I gave her in charge—this is my shawl.

Prisoner. You sold my shawl to get tea, and said, "You can have the loan of my old shawl, "and I said, "Very well. "Witness. I did not—I did not sell her shawl to Emma Perkins—she left a few things with me for board and lodging—she never paid me anything.

JOHN BUTT ( police-constable K 197.) The prisoner was given in charge—she refused to give up the shawl, and said she would sooner break it in pieces than the prosecutrix should have it—she came to the station without an officer.
Prisoner's Defence. The prosecutrix lent me the shawl, when she had sold mine to Emma Perkins.

GUILTY . Aged 48.—
Confined Two Months.

1663.
GEORGE SIMMONDS was indicted
for stealing, on the 13th of April, 10 1/2 lbs., weight of lead, value 2s., the goods of
William Nyren and others, his masters; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 31.—
Confined Four Months.

1664.
MAJOR BURTON was indicted
for stealing, on the 24th of April, 13lbs. weight of lead, value 2s. 6d., the goods of
James Patrick Murphy, and fixed to a certain building; against the Statute, &c.

WILLIAM SHEEN (police-constable K 275.) I received information about some lead, and I went and apprehended the prisoner at his father's house—before I spoke to the prisoner about lead, he began to cry, and said he had stolen some lead, and he had cut it off, with another boy, from Mr. Murphy's premises, in North Gate-lane—this lead had been sent by a marine-store dealer to the station—I have fitted it to the premises—it fits exactly.
RACHEL RAYNEK . I am the wife of John Rayner, a marine-store dealer, at Stratford. The prisoner came and offered this lead for sale—I had some suspicion, and informed the police.
JOSEPH LINNEY . I live with James Patrick Murphy, at Marsh-gate, West Ham. The policeman showed me this lead—I fitted it on the engine-house—it fitted exactly.
Prisoner. A boy told me to get up and cut two pieces off, and then he got up and cut some off himself.

GUILTY . * Aged 11.—
Confined Ten Days, and
Whipped.

1665.
ELLEN BARRY was indicted
for stealing, on the 26th of April, 1 shawl, value 6s., the goods of
Mary Kentain.

MARY KENTAIN . I lived at Mr. Scott's, in High-street, Bromley. The prisoner lodged at the same place—on the 26th of April I missed a shawl, which I had laid on the scale at the corner of the counter in Mr. Scott's shop—I told the prisoner—she said she was sorry for it, and persuaded me to go to the pawnbroker's to look for it—I went with her to Mr. Crawley's, the pawnbroker, and I inquired, while she was with me, for the shawl—they said they did not recollect taking one in—I afterwards went to Mr. Isaacs, a pawn
broker—I found it there—this is it.
Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. What is it worth? A. About 5s.—it was pawned for 1s. 6d.
ELIZABETH NICHOLLS . I live at the Bow station. I found this duplicate for this shawl on the prisoner.
JSOSEPHS BENNETT . I am apprentice to Mr. Isaac, a pawnbroker. This shawl was pawned by the prisoner—I gave this duplicate for it.
PETER M'CARDELL (police-sergeant K 4.) I took the prisoner.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Confined Four Months.

1666.
WILLIAM DAY was indicted
for unlawfully obtaining 6 shillings, 2 pence, and 4 halfpence, from
James Claringbold, by false pretences.
NOT GUILTY .

1667.
ROBERT WILSON was indicted
for stealing, on 18th of April, 2 breast-pins and chain, value 16s., the goods of
Frederick Shemeld, from his person.

FREDERICK SHEMELD . I am a chaser, and live in Clerkenwell-close. On Tuesday, the 18th of April, I was at a tavern at Greenwich, at the fair time—about half-past ten o'clock in the evening I was passing the bar, to leave the tavern, and saw the prisoner—he said nothing, but came close to my person, and took a union pin out of my scarf—the space before the bar was very crowded, but I can speak positively to the prisoner—I had never seen him before—he passed it to another person—I seized the man he passed it to, collared him, and got him down into a corner of the room—I was immediately set upon by six, eight, or ten persons, and was dreadfully treated—I was not able to attend to my business for some days—the man whom I took hold of got away—I bled very much at the time—I got some hot water—it was perhaps half an hour before I could leave the house—I then left, and in going up High-street, Greenwich, I saw the prisoner—I attempted to seize him, and in passing between two oyster-stalls, or something, I was pushed back by a party, and he made his escape—I afterwards got into a fly, and went into the Elephant and Castle—I felt fatigued, and went into the Alfred's Head, near there, and saw the prisoner there—that must have been past one o'clock in the morning—I pointed him out to the police, and he was taken.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. What time was it you had the pin stolen? A. I should say about half-past ten o'clock—I had gone to the fair about six o'clock—I had not dined there—I had drunk very little—I had been to one other public-house, and about the park—I was not at all intoxi
cated—I had two or three friends with me, but I was the first who went down stairs—my friend Davis was following me—after I was ill-treated, I went to another house, where the fly stood at the door, and in going to that house I saw the prisoner—I remained in that public-house, I suppose, half an hour—I did not drink—I was much hurt, but not much confused—I did not notice the prisoner's dress so much as his features—I noticed nothing particular about his dress—he had a hat on, I am quite certain—I and my friend did not talk over the description of the person—I did not describe him to my friend, nor he to me—when I met him in High-street, I said, "That is the man who robbed me"—he was passing me at the time, meeting me—he ran away.

JOHN DAVIS . I am a chaser. I was with Shemeld at Greenwich fair—he was coming out of the tavern—I did not see the robbery committed—I saw him directly afterwards—I and my friends were pushed back by a quan
tity of persons, there might be a dozen, and kept back on the staircase—I came home afterwards with the prosecutor, and was with him when he saw the prisoner in the street—he pointed him out to me—I was with him after
wards at the Alfred's Head, and saw the prisoner there—he is the person I saw at Greenwich.

Cross-examined. Q. The man did not give you much opportunity of ex
amining his countenance? A. No, but I had seen him previously in the house—when I saw him at Greenwich he was under a lamp-post—I saw his countenance well—I have no doubt the man I saw in the street, was the man I had seen before in the public-house—I had noticed him in front of the bar before the occurrence took place—I do not know that I have said so before—I believe I have—when I saw him in the street he made off as soon as he could—neither 1 nor Shemeld had described the person of the man, I am confident, nor talked about it.

WILLIAM DERRY . I am a policeman. I took the prisoner into custody on Wednesday morning, the 19th, at the Alfred's Head—I told him he was charged with robbing a gentleman at Greenwich of a union-pin—he did not say anything, but immediately threw himself on his back, and resisted most Violently.
Cross-examined. Q. How long after you collared him did he throw him-self on his back? A. Almost immediately.

GUILTY . Aged 27.—
Transported for Ten Years.

1668.
MICHAEL MACK was indicted
for stealing, on the 15th of April, 1 stock and 3 bits, value 1l. 11s.; 3 saws, 19s.; 2 squares, 6s.; 4 planes, 1l.; 1 plough, 1l.; and 1 gauge, 3s.; the goods of
Edwin Miles.

ESDWINS MILES . I am a carpenter, and live in Marlborough-street, Green
wich. This gimlet and three centre-bits are mine—I saw them safe on Fri
day night at No. 19, Ship and Billet-row, where I was working—I left them there locked up in a back room—I missed them on Saturday morning at half-past six o'clock, on going to work, and found the lock burst open—the pri
soner had been working there a day or two previous—I missed three saws, four planes, and these things—I have never recovered any but these bits and the gimlet—I know these are all mine—I have a particular mark on one—I have been in the habit of using them daily.

CHARLES PHYPERS . I am a carpenter, and live at Royal-hill, Greenwich, On the 15th of April I bought these three centre-bits and gimlet of the pri
soner for 10d.—I asked how he came by them—he said they were given to him by a gentleman, in East-lane, Greenwich, who was going abroad.

Prisoner. I never said so; I said I had found them in the rubbish. Wit
ness. He did not.
EDWARD BUCKLEY . I am a policeman. I apprehended the prisoner—I found nothing in his possession.
Prisoner's Defence. I found the things in the rubbish; I did not think they were of any value, and put them into my pocket.

GSUILTY . Aged 33.—
Confined Two Months.

1669.
MICHAEL GLEESON was indicted
for stealing, on the 17th of April, 1 handkerchief, value 8d., the goods of
George Wigan, from his person.

GEORGE WIGAN . I am a musical instrument maker, and live in Vauxhall-road. On the 17th of April, about half-past four o'clock in the afternoon, I was at Greenwich fair—I felt a tug at my left coat pocket, turned, and saw my handkerchief in the prisoner's hand—it had been in my pocket some minutes before—there was a constable behind me, who took the prisoner—this is my handkerchief.

Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. You were standing opposite Richard
son's booth? A. Yes—I turned round immediately on feeling the tug, and saw the handkerchief, the prisoner, and the constable—I cannot say whether the handkerchief was in my pocket or hanging out.

THOMAS NORRIS (police-constable A 175.) I was on duty in Greenwich fair on the 17th of April, and saw the prisoner take the prosecutor's pocket in his hand, and feel if there was anything in it—he then put his hand in, and took this handkerchief out—I took him into custody—the crowd was very great—I could not keep hold of him—another constable took him before he got out of my sight—he did not get more than two yards from me.

Cross-examined. Q. You were on the look out for thieves that after
noon? A. Yes—I saw the prisoner attempt to pick several pockets, and others also—I did not see any of them really pick a pocket—another officer,

named Millingham, was in my company—I do not know his number—he belongs to the B division—the Magistrate did not require his evidence—he was before the Magistrate, and gave his evidence, but his deposition was not taken—he is here now—I did not bring him—he has other cases here—I saw the prisoner make two or three attempts to pick pockets—I can swear to three times—I have inquired after his character—I have not found it a very good one—I went to where he had been in service nine months—the policeman, D 146, stated that he had been the constant associate of thieves—I do not know that I ought to have taken the prisoner into custody for at
tempting to pick a pocket—I have been in the police eight years—if there was nothing in the pocket, he could not take it—I know that attempting to pick a pocket is a misdemeanour—I have had such a case—I know there was nothing in the pockets that he could take, because nothing was taken—I did not con
sider that he had committed any offence for which I could take him—we sometimes get expenses on summary convictions before a Magistrate—we do not for misdemeanours—we, of course, get expenses here in cases of felony—I have heard that I could have taken him for merely lifting a pocket up, but I did not consider it sufficient for me to take him—I did not run after him—I took him on the spot, as soon as he took the handkerchief out—there was a great crowd—I had been following him about the fair—I first saw him in the crowd, within about a hundred yards of where he stole this handkerchief—there were a great number of persons between me and him, as I followed him through the fair—he escaped from my hand after I seised him, but the other constable seised him, without my losing sight of him—some of the persons in the crowd came between me and him, but he did not get two yards from me—the other constable was on my right side, the side nearest the prisoner, and close to him—as soon as he got out of my hand the officer laid hold of him—the signature to this deposition is mine—(read)—"I took the handkerchief from the prisoner, who escaped in the crowd; I did not lose sight of him, and the prisoner was taken by another constable."

GUILTY . Aged 15.—
Confined Six Months.

1670.
THOMAS HOCKODAY was indicted
for stealing, on the 21st of April, 11 penkives, value 16s. 6d., the goods of
James Cross.

HENRY GLAISER . I am apprentice to Mr. James Cross, a stationer, at Greenwich. On Friday morning, the 21st of April, I came into the shop, and saw the prisoner there with a card of knives in his hand—he put them down, and asked how much they were each—I saw another card of knives under his coat, and asked what he had got there—he said, "Nothing"—I said "You have"—he put the knives down, and ran out of the shop—there was no one else in the shop—I called Mr. Cross, who ran after him—I fol
lowed shortly after, overtook Mr. Cross, and spoke to a policeman, who ran after him—he got away in the grove—I am sure he is the person—these are the knives he had under his coat—they are Mr. Cross's.

DANIEL MOYNAHAN (police-constable R 104.) I was on duty at Croom's-hill, Greenwich, on Friday, the 21st of April. In consequence of information, I pursued the prisoner—I lost sight of him in Blackheath-grove—I only saw his back.
JOSEPH GREEN . I am a policeman. I apprehended the prisoner in the Broadway, Deptford, on the 21st of April, in consequence of information.

Prisoner's Defence. I was returning home from my work, the police
man stopped me, and said one of his men wanted me; the lad at first said he could not swear to me, and next day he said I was the man.

GUILTY . Aged 10.—
Confined Three Months.

1671.
MARY ANN BROWN was indicted
for stealing, on the 19th of April, 1 purse, value 6d.; 1 knife, 2d.; 3 half-crowns, 6 shillings, 6 six-pences, and 2 halfpence; the property of
Simon Watling, from his person.

SIMON WATLING . I am a Greenwich pensioner. On the 19th of April, about twelve, or half-past twelve o'clock in the day, I met the prisoner in the street, between Deptford and Greenwich—I never knew her before—I do not know whether she spoke to me, or I to her, hut we went and drank to
gether outside a public-house, sitting on the bench—before I met her I had a purse with three half-crowns, three shillings, six sixpences, two halfpence, a knife, and an old ring in it—it belonged to me—I lost my purse—I cannot say whether I dropped it on the ground, or how it was, but it was found in the prisoner's lap—I did not feel anything happen to my person while she was with me—this is the purse, knife, and ring, now produced—I was not sober.

MARY ANN PRESTON . I was sitting at the beer-shop, taking refreshment, and saw the prisoner and prosecutor drinking together—I saw him take the purse from his pocket, shake it on the stool, and say that money was to take him home—he put it into his pocket again—about five minutes after, I saw the prisoner get up, and take the purse from his pocket—this is the purse.

Prisoner. Q. Did you not hear me say to the prosecutor, "There is your purse," and see me deliver it into his hands? A. You did not give up the purse till you were accused—you said he was your husband, and you had a right to the purse.
WILLIAM TURNER . I am a policeman. I took the prisoner into custody—she said the prosecutor was her husband.
Prisoner. Q. Did not the prosecutor throw the money on the table, and did not you take it up? A. The money was spread on the table—you had no money.

p.hi: "The prisoner put in a written defence, stating that the prosecutor pulled out his purse several times; that she persuaded him to keep it in his pocket; that on his putting it in he left one end hanging out; that she took hold of it and placed it in his hand, and he scattered the contents on the table, and that the females fetched a policeman, and gave her in charge."

div1.p:
GUILTY. Aged 44.—Recommended to mercy. —
Confined Two Months.

1672.
GEORGE GRAY was indicted
for stealing, on the 15th of Aug., at
Lee, 1 cash-box, value 6d.; 16 spoons, 3l. 8s.; 1 pair of sugar-tongs, 8s.; 1 sovereign, 1 half-sovereign, 9 half-crowns, 106 shillings, 77 sixpences, 28 groats, 1 half-crown, 1 sixpence, 1 groat, and 1 foreign silver coin, value 1s., the property of
Henry Couldery, in his dwelling-house.

HENRY COULDERY . I keep the Royal Oak, in the parish of Lee. On Monday, the 15th of August, about two o'clock in the afternoon, the prisoner and another person, came to my house, and directly ran up into the club-room—there is a passage between the club-room and my bed-room—the doors are opposite each other—I kept a cash-box in my bedroom—the pri
soner called for two slices of bread and cheese, and a pint of stout, and after
wards for another pint of stout, and a screw of tobacco—when I went up the third time, the prisoner said, "Landlord, will you let the door be open, for your room is so excessively hot"—I opened the club-room door at his request, and went down again—I observed a pocket-book on the table—about half an hour afterwards I saw the prisoner and the other coming down stairs—(Mrs.

Couldery had then been up into the bed-room)—they went out without pay
ing for their refreshment—I followed them as far at the threshold of the door—I then waited to know if my bed-room was safe—after some communication from my wife, I followed the prisoner—I overtook him about 100 yards from my house, and took him into custody—I do not know that he saw me before I came up to him—he could have seen me, because the ground rises—the other man went across the fields towards the Lee-road—I have since seen my cash-box—at the time it was stolen, it contained gold, half-crowns, shillings, and sixpences—it was in a chest of drawers in my bed-room.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. How far is the club-room from the bed-room? A. The passage runs between the two—there had been three other persons drinking in the club-room besides these two—I had never seen the prisoner before—I have two servants.

MR. BALLANTINE. Q. When the prisoner and the other first came, were there any persons up in the club-room? A. There was—they did not re
main there all the while—two of them came down about a minute before these two—they paid for what they had, and went away—the other one came down with these two—he was a deaf and dumb gentleman, living in the neighbourhood, who used to come there regularly every afternoon—the door of the club-room is in the centre of the room—the prisoner might have closed the door so that the persons in the club-room could not see him go into the bed-room—I did not know either of the other two persons—they had been in the house before, and up into the club-room—I have never seen them since—I did not observe the prisoner in conversation with any of the other per
sons in the club-room—they seemed to be keeping separate company.

AMELIA COULDERY . I am the prosecutor's wife. On the 15th of Aug. I went up into the bed-room by my husband's direction—as I went up I met some persons coming down stairs—the prisoner was one of them—I am quite sure of him—I went into my bed-room, and found the drawer had been broken open, and the cash-box gone—I had seen it half an hour before—it then had gold and silver in it—I called out to my husband—there was no marks of the drawer having been forced—I saw the two persons come in be
fore the prisoner and the other man, soon after two o'clock—the prisoner came not long after with the other man—I was up in the room at the time the prisoner was there, and saw him in the room—the club-room door is usually kept open.

WILLIAM ARCHER . I am a gardener, and live at Lee. I was at Mr. Coul
dery's house on the 15th of Aug., and saw the prisoner—I was in the club-room several times—I was sitting at the bottom of the stairs at the time the prisoner and the other man came down stairs, and left the house—I followed the prisoner with Mr. Couldery—we took him—I told him I took him on suspicion of robbing Mr. Couldery of a cash-box—he denied it.

CHARLES WRIGHT . I am a carpenter, living at Lee. On the 16th of Aug. I was going from Church-street, through Church-passage, to Lee, and under a hedge there I found this cash-box and a parcel near it, in which I found some plate—I had heard of the robbery the night before, and took it to the prose
cutor—Mr. Couldery has since pointed out to me the spot where the prisoner was taken, and it was about eighty yards beyond that that the cash-box was found—I showed Mr. Couldery where I found it.

HENRY COULDERY
re-examined. Wright showed me where he found the cash-box—the prisoner took that course on leaving my house, and would pass that spot—I took the prisoner against a large tree about eighty yards from there.
JAMES HIGGS (police-constable R 233.) I searched the prisoner and found

this piece of iron-wire, and pocket-book on him—I produce the lock of the drawer which was broken open—there is one mark on it which distinctly cor
responds with the point of this iron—I also saw some marks on the drawer. John Wyatt. I am a smith, and live at Lee. This iron is a bottle-jack skewer—I examined the lock of the drawer, and found the bolt had been forced down by some sharp-pointed instrument—this iron would have done it—I also saw marks on the wood work of the drawer, which I have no doubt were made by that instrument.
Cross-examined. A. Any sharp thing would produce the same effect? A. It might—I have none of the wood work here—there is an impression on the bolt of the lock.
MR. BALLANTINE. Q. The wood work is on a chest of drawers, is it not? A. Yes, and on the drawer itself—the marks correspond in size and shape with this instrument.

JOHN CARPENTER (police-sergeant R 84.) I searched the prisoner's lodg
ing the night after he was apprehended—he told me previously where he lived—I found a quantity of keys, a dark-lantern, and other articles there, which I produce—I took Wyatt to the prosecutor's house by the Magistrate's order—I found marks on the drawer corresponding with the top of this skewer—it is rather a peculiar shape—it exactly fits the marks in the wood work of the drawer—there were two marks—I have no doubt they were made by this—the marks were about a quarter of an inch apart, both on one side, directly oppo
site the bolt of the lock.

FRANCIS BARNARD (police-constable R 134.) I had charge of the pri
soner, to take him from Maidstone to Greenwich, on board a steam-packet—when the packet stopped at Cray, in Essex, I found he had escaped—he had been below—I went to his house, but could not find him.

ARTHUR PASCOE (police-constable H 141.) In consequence of information, I took the prisoner into custody on Friday, the 14th of April, near the Liver
pool-road—a person was with me who pointed him out to me—the prisoner saw the person put up his finger to me, and directly started off as hard as he could go—I ran after him a considerable distance, and succeeded at last in taking him—I asked if his name was Gray—he said it was not—I said I thought it was—he said it was not—I took him by the collar, and took him to the station—as I was afterwards taking him from the station to a cab, he said I was the only one who could do it for him—I understood what he meant, but made little or no reply—after we were in the cab he kept talking to me in the same strain respecting money—I did not answer—he asked me if I heard what he said—I said I did—he said, "I am afraid you don't heed; if you don't, I am cooked; I don't think you understand business."
Cross-examined. Q. Was any one present at this conversation but you and him? A. No—the party who identified him was sitting on the coach-box.

HENRY COULDERY
re-examined. The pocket-book I saw on the table in the club-room was similar to the one produced—it was a red morocco one—this plate and cash-box is mine, and what I missed from the drawer—the prisoner was about sixty yards from my house when I began to run after him—the other man did not run in that direction—the prisoner was the only one that took that direction—he might have thrown away the cash-box without my seeing him do so—he had to go under two arches, which would obstruct the sight.

GUILTY . * Aged 30.—
Transported for Ten Years.

1673.
THOMAS SMITH and
EDWARD READING were indicted for
feloniously and knowingly uttering a counterfeit half-crown to
Margaret But
ler, on the 18th of April; they having been previously convicted of uttering counterfeit coin.

CALEB EDWARD POWELL . I am assistant solicitor to the Mint. I pro
duce a copy of the record of the conviction of Thomas Smith at the Hertford sessions in Jan., 1842—I also produce a copy of the record of the conviction of Edward Reading at this Court at the Jan. sessions, 1838—I have examined both with the original records, and they are true copies—(read.)

WILLIAM FARRELL . I am a schoolmaster, and live at Wynford, in Hert-fordshire. In 1842 I was in the Rural Police—I know the prisoner Smith—I was present in Court, at Hertford, when he was tried for uttering a counter
feit shilling—he was convicted, and came out of gaol in Jan. last year.
JAMES BROOK (police-constable L 118.) In Jan., 1838, I was present in this Court when Reading was tried and convicted of uttering counterfeit coin.

JAMES FLEMING . I am in the general line, and live at Greenwich. On the evening of the 18th of April I was at my stall, between seven and eight o'clock—the prisoner Smith came and asked for a penny polony and a penny cake, and gave me a shilling—I gave it to my wife, who was with me—she gave him change, and he went away.
Smith. Q. What sort of a shilling was it, a new or old one? A. It was not a new one exactly; it was a dirty looking one.

SARAH ANN FLEMING . I am the wife of James Fleming. On the evening of the 18th of April he sold a cake and a polony to a man, and gave me the shilling he received in payment—I gave change for it, and put it into my pocket—I had some sixpences there, but no other shilling, I am sure—about an hour after I went to give change again, and found it was a bad one—I had no other shilling—I gave it to the officer next morning—I am sure it was the same shilling I had received from my husband.
Smith. Q. Who did you give the change to? A. I did not take particular notice who it was.

RICHARD FOLKES (police-constable R 203.) I was on duty in the neigh
bourhood of Greenwich on Tuesday evening, the 18th of April, about six o'clock—I saw the prisoners in Stockwell-street, Greenwich, in company with a female, loitering about, from half to three-quarters of an hour—it was fair time—I saw them go towards Straits-mouth, which is near Fleming's stall—I saw no more of them that day—next morning Fleming came to me, told me something, and gave me a shilling, which I produce—I believe he marked it before he gave it me.

MARGARET BUTLER . I keep the Painter's Arms public-house, Strait's-mouth, Greenwich. On the evening of the 18th of April the prisoners came to my house together—I served Smith with a pint of ale—Reading was with him at the time—Smith gave me a half-crown in payment—I immediately observed that it was a bad one—I marked it, and put it on the shelf-I told Smith it was a bad one, and I should not return it to him—he said nothing, but immediately gave me a good one—both of the prisoners partook of the ale—Reading said he did not think I was any good myself—after they drank the ale they left the house—I sent Wilson, my waiter, after them—I after
wards gave the half-crown to the policeman.

Smith. I was not aware it was bad; I did not wish to have it returned, but to have it put into the fire. Witness. He did not ask me to return it, or to put it into the fire—he did not say a word about it.

COURT. Q. Did either of them say anything after you refused to return the half-crown? A. Reading used many insulting words, but I cannot say what they were, for I went immediately to look after my waiter, and when I came down they were gone.

JAMES WILSON . I am waiter to Mrs. Butler. On the 18th of April, in consequence of directions from my mistress, I went after the prisoners—they walked away from our house—I saw them at the Earl Grey, at the corner of Skelton's-lane, about a hundred yards from my mistress's house—they were going into the house—they saw me following them, and turned round, and Smith said, "Are you following me, Sir?"—I said, "Never mind, you must mind what you are about"—the police came up, and I gave them into cus
tody—they were both in the attitude of fighting me when I turned round.
Smith. He said at Greenwich that it was Reading that spoke to him. Witness. It was Smith.

SAMUEL ARCHER (police-constable R 54.) I was on duty near the Earl Grey beer-house on the night of the 18th of April, and received the prisoners in custody from Wilson—I took them to Mrs. Butler's, and received from her this half-crown, which I produce—I found 2s. 5d. on Smith, good money, and 4d. on Reading—Reading was taken sick in the station—we took him out into the air, and he spat 3s. 6d. in good money out of his mouth into the yard—he appeared to bring it up from his stomach—Smith said that his cha
racter was well known, that he was not a character anybody knew any harm about.
MR. JOHN FIELD . I am inspector of counterfeit coin to the Mint. I have examined this half-crown and shilling—they are both counterfeit in all respects.

Smith's Defence. Fleming states that he cannot tell whether it was an old or a new shilling; he gave it to his wife; she said at first she had it four hours, and now she says it was hardly an hour before she had occasion to go to her pocket to give change; she cannot say it was me gave the half-crown, and it is very strange that she should not know who it was, and he should; the truth of it is the policeman made a search about for some bad money; he found this half-crown, and has persuaded Fleming to say it was me that gave it him; I know nothing about it; I was very tipsy when I went to Mrs. Butler's; I did not wish her to return the half-crown, but gave her another; I have worked hard for my living since I have been out of prison.
Reading's Defence. I have been at work for these eighteen months; it was fair time, and I was very tipsy.

SMITH—
GUILTY . Aged 23.

REDDING—
GUILTY . Aged 24.

1674.
JOHN MASON was indicted
for feloniously assaulting
Ellen Mason, on the 6th of May, and cutting and wounding her in and upon the left side of the head, with intent to do her some grievous bodily harm.

ELLEN MASON . I am the prisoner's wife, and live in Prince's-fields, Deptford. On Saturday night, the 6th of May, my husband came home, be
tween ten and eleven o'clock, drunk—we had a few words respecting his rela
tions—I rather provoked him, and was quite as much in fault as he was—I went towards the door—he followed me into the yard, and hit me in the face with his hand or fist, I am not sure which—I believe I took a piece of wood off the paling, and attempted to throw it at him, and he struck me twice with it on the side of my head—it did not knock me down—I was down at the time—I was not knocked down, I fell—I think I must have kicked my foot against a stone—my head felt very painful, and bled a great deal—I thought
something stuck in my head at the time—it was a bit of a nail—this is the stick—I have not been ill at all, or confined.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. I suppose all the injury done was from this nail? A. Yes—this is the piece of wood which I myself tore off, as my boy informed me—I was going to throw it at him when he took it from me—he had not got it in his hand when he came in—after he hit me in the face I struck him on the top of his hat—that was before he struck me with this.

MARY ANDREWS . I am the wife of William Andrews, a pensioner at Deptford—I heard them quarrelling on this evening—I saw the prisoner striking his wife twice with this stick—he was going to strike a third blow, which I prevented—I was there at the beginning—he got the stick off my gate, and struck her on the head.
EDWARD DOWLING . I am a surgeon, and live at Deptford—I examined the prosecutrix, and found a slight wound on her head, as if made by a nail.
GUILTY of an Assault. Aged 52.

p.rs: To enter into his own recognizances of 50l. to keep the peace for two years.

div1.p:
1675.
GEORGE HILLIER and
GEORGE JONES were indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of May, 1 knife, value 1s., the goods of
John Pilkington.

JOHN PILKINGTON . I am a watchmaker, and live in High-street, Wool
wich. On the evening of the 8th of May, the prisoners came to my shop together, and asked to look at some knives—I showed them some—they wished one smaller—I went to the other side of the shop to get them, and said they were 1s.—they offered 8d., and went out—I afterwards missed a knife—this now produced is it.

DANIEL RIORDEN . I am a police-sergeant. In consequence of information, I went after the prisoners, and saw them in High-street, running both to
gether—I took Jones—Hillier was stopped by two soldiers—I found this knife next morning over a wall, in the direction in which they had run.
Jones. We ran, because it rained very hard.
NOT GUILTY .

1676.
WILLIAM STAGG was indicted
for assaulting
Mary Ann Latten, with intent, &c.

GUILTY .—
Confined Two Years.

1677.
WILLIAM JONES and
CHARLES PHILLIPS were indicted
for stealing, on the 18th of April, 1 handkerchief, value 2d., the goods of a man unknown, from his person.

JAMES M'LOCHLAN (police-constable C 125.) I was in Greenwich-park, on the 18th of April, between five and six o'clock in the evening—I saw the prisoners there together—I saw Phillips take this handkerchief from gen
tleman's pocket, and pass it to Jones—I do not know who the gentleman was—he was in the crowd—I took Jones, and found this handkerchief in his pocket—Phillips escaped.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Did Jones claim the handkerchief? A. No—we could not get Phillips, as the mob was so great—the gentleman was standing looking at a party playingat kiss-in-the-ring—I was in plain clothes.
Phillips. You let us get away from the crowd. Witness. No, I took Jones directly.
JAMES WILLIAM BURRIDGE (police-constable V 160.) I was in the Park
in plain clothes—I saw Phillips take this handkerchief from a gentleman, and hand it to Jones—I pursued Phillips, but he got out of the Park—I found Phillips in Gravel-lane, in the Borough.
Cross-examined. Q. Who was the gentleman this handkerchief belonged to? A. That I cannot say.
(Jones received a good character.)

JONES—
GUILTY. Aged 15.—Recommended to mercy. —
Confined Four Months.

PHILLIPS—
GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined Six Months.

1678.
GEORGE RIXON was indicted
for stealing, on the 3rd of April, 2 sovereigns, the monies of
Thomas Whitcomb Crispin; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined One Month.

1679.
JOHN GLENNING was indicted
for stealing, on the 18th of April, 1 paper-bag, value 1/2 d., and 1lb. weight of gingerbread, 1s., of a man whose name is unknown, from his person.

ROBERT BURNETT (police-constable C 120.) I was on duty at Greenwich fair, on the 18th of April—I saw the prisoner in company with some other boys—I saw him follow a gentleman, and take out of his pocket a bag of gingerbread nuts—I took him directly—the gentleman came part of the way to the station, but he had a ticket to go by the steam-boat—it was just getting dusk, and when I got near the station, he was gone—I had not asked his name, as I was not aware he was going—this is the bag of nuts—I asked the gentleman if he had lost anything of value, and he turned round, and said this was his property.

GUILTY . Aged 13.—
Confined Three Weeks.

1680.
CHARLES NICHOLSON and
CHARLES ANSLOW
were in-dicted for stealing, on the 18th of April, 1 handkerchief, value 6d.; the goods of
John Foster Hillman, from his person; to which

NICHOLSON pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined Fourteen Days.

JOHN FOSTER HILLMAN . I am clerk to Mr. Hillman, a merchant in the City. On the 18th of April, between nine and ten o'clock at night, I was in Greenwich fair—I heard some one call—I turned, and saw my handkerchief in the constable's hand—it was safe about a minute before—this is it.

HENRY FOWLER (police-constable E 111.) I was at Greenwich fair, and saw the prisoners following the prosecutor, and talking together in an under tone—I saw Nicholson take this handkerchief out of the prosecutor's pocket, and give it to Anslow, who had been covering Nicholson, and was near enough to see what he did—I took him, and took the handkerchief from him.
Anslow. I had it not in my possession at all. Witness. I took it from him.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

ANSLOW—
GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined Fourteen Days.

1681.
CHARLES COLEMAN was indicted
for stealing, on the 19th of April, 2 breast-pins and chain, value 5l.; the goods of
Thomas John Wat
kins, from his person.

THOMAS JOHN WATKINS . I am a wine-merchant. On the night of the 19th of April I was at Greenwich fair—I went to the Mitre tavern with a female—I had a gold pin in my scarf, and missed it after I had been there a
short time—this is it—(looking at it)—I had this in my scarf when I went into the Mitre—it is two pins and a chain.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. You had been drinking more wine than you ought to have done? A. I regret to say that was the case—I had not known the female till that evening—I do not consider that I was in a condition to say whether she was sober or not—I was on some business, and met with two friends—I dined with them, and that induced me to go to the fair.

ELLEN KING . I live in Sheffield-street, Lincoln's-inn-fields—I am assist
ant to a dress-maker—I was at Greenwich fair on the night of the 19th of April with a female companion—I missed her, and while I was looking for her I met with Mr. Watkins—we then went to the Mitre tavern—there was a great crowd—it was just as the fair was over—we were just against the coffee-room door, when the prisoner put his head in my face, and at the same time he drew the pin out of the gentleman's scarf—I caught hold of him by his handkerchief, and called for a police-constable—I kept the prisoner, with the assistance of the crowd, till the police-constable came—I afterwards saw the pin picked off the floor—it was given to me—I handed it over to the person at the bar—I believe this to be it.

Cross-examined. Q. Where does the dress-maker live to whom you are assistant? A. At No. 10, Sheffield-street—I reside in the house, and work for her in my own room—there is a shop there—this happened between eleven and twelve o'clock at night—I had missed my companion for about half an hour—I had not joined company with the prosecutor ten minutes when this happened—there was a great crowd—I had not been taking anything to drink myself—I saw the pin picked up, but I cannot say whether a man or a woman picked it up—I asked for it, and it was handed to me, but I really cannot tell whether it was by a man or a woman—I did not see my friend in the crowd—there were others there that I knew, men and women; but no one that I went with—I had seen them in the fair before I went to the Mitre—I was perfectly sober—I went down with a friend—the prosecutor joined me—I was alone at that time—I had never seen him before.

MARGARET ROBERTS . I am cook at the Mitre, at the corner, near the church, at Greenwich. Between eleven and twelve o'clock on the night of the 19th of April, a pin was handed to me by a female—I wrapped it in paper, and put it on a shelf, till I gave it to the policeman.

Cross-examined. Q. Was it given you by the last witness? A. It might be her, or it might not—I believe she was the woman—I was asked at the Magistrate's if she was tipsy, and I said, "She might be, or might not"—there was a great crowd, I could not tell.

JOSEPH BUCKMASTER (police-constable R 42.) I was on duty about twelve o'clock at night—I was called into the Mitre—I saw Mr. Watkins, the prisoner, and King—I spoke to King; she appeared to me to be perfectly sober—the prosecutor was rather intoxicated—I received this pin from a female at the bar—I cannot say whether it was Roberts.

GUILTY . Aged 34.—
Transported for Ten Years.

1682.
EDWARD COCKRAN and
EDWIN GOODWIN were indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of April, 1 handkerchief, value 4s.; the goods of
Peter Walker, from his person; to which

COCKRAN pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined Six Months.

PETER WALKER . I am a shipwright, and live at Blackwall. On the 18th of April I was at Greenwich fair—I saw my handkerchief in the hands of Kemp, the officer—I claimed it in the prisoner's presence—it had been in my possession five minutes before.

GEORGE KEMP (police-constable N 82.) I was on duty in Greenwich fair on the 18th of April—I saw the prisoners in company, attempting several gentlemen's pockets—I saw Mr. Walker and another gentleman walking along arm in arm—the prisoners followed them close, and put their hands into each of the gentlemen's pockets—Cockran took up Mr. Walker's pocket, and Goodman the other—Cockran got a handkerchief out of Mr. Walker's pocket, and put it behind him for his companion to take it—I was behind—I took hold of him and the handkerchief—I found two other handkerchiefs on him—Goodman was quite close to him, and could see what he did.

THOMAS BURCHAM (police-constable H 33.) I was with Kemp—I saw the prisoners trying several gentlemen's pockets—they then went behind the pro
secutor, Cockran lifted his coat, and took his handkerchief out—Goodman was covering him by walking close behind him—in going to the station Cockram chucked his cap off behind him, and I found another handkerchief in it—the gentleman who was in company with Mr. Walker did not lose anything
Goodman. I know nothing of this lad. I did not not put my hand into any pockets.

GOODMAN—
GUILTY . Aged 16.—
Confined Six Months.

1683.
HENRY WELLS and
EDWARD BROWN were indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of April, 1 handkerchief, value 1s., the goods of
John Higgs, from his person; and that Brown had been before convicted of felony; to which

BROWN pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 13.—
Transported for Ten Years.—Parkhurst.

JOHN HIGGS . I am a carpenter, and live at Pimlico. On the 17th of April I was at Greenwich fair—about eight o'clock at night I felt a hand in my pocket—I turned and caught my handkerchief, which both the prisoners had hold of—while I was struggling with them for it a part of it was torn off—I kept that part in my hand—the prisoners were taken into custody—this is my handkerchief.
Wells. It was not in my hand; I am quite innocent; I was four yards from Brown. Witness. It was in Wells's hand—he was close by Brown.

GEORGE KEMP (police-constable N 82.) I was at the fair between eight and nine o'clock—I saw the two prisoners together—I watched them, and saw Wells put his hand into the prosecutor's pocket, and take the handker
chief out—both the prisoners had hold of it together—I took them, and searched Wells—I found another handkerchief round his neck, under the black one.

THOMAS BURCHAM (police-constable H 33.) I was with Kemp—I saw Wells put bis hand into the prosecutor's pocket, and take out the handker
chief—both the prisoners had hold of it—I took Brown—I found on him three handkerchiefs, one round bis body, one round his neck, and one he threw down.
(Wells received a good character.)

WELLS—
GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Six Months.

1684.
JOSEPH WATKINS and
JOHN NEAVES were indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of April, 1 handkerchief, value 2s., the goods of a man unknown, from his person.

GEORGE KEMP (police-constable N 82.) I was on duty in Greenwich fair on the 17th of April—I saw the prisoners there—I watched them for some time, and saw Neaves put his hand into a gentleman's pocket, take a handkerchief

out, and pass it to Watkins, who put it into the flap of his trowsers—I and my brother officer took the prisoners into custody, but the crowd being great, we lost the gentleman—in going to the station Watkins took the handkerchief out of his trowsers, and chucked it down.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Where were you standing? A. Close at their back—I could not touch the gentleman, for directly they got the handkerchief they made a push, and I pushed after them—I distinctly saw Neaves take the handkerchief—they were playing in front of a show, and the people were standing close, looking at the clown.

THOMAS BURCHAM (police-constable H 33.) I was with Kemp—I saw Neaves take this handkerchief from a gentleman's pocket, and pass it to Watkins, who put it into his trowsers' pocket—it came out of his trowsers on the way to the station.

Watkins's Defence. I saw this handkerchief lying down, with some bread and meat in it; I saw some men, and asked them if it was theirs; they said no; I and my sister eat the bread and meat; I put the handkerchief into my pocket; I was looking at Richardson's show, and took the handker
chief oat to wipe my nose, and the officer seised me.
(Neave received a good character.)

WATKINS*—
GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Twelve Months.

NEAVES—
GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Confined Six Months.

1685.
GEORGE SHAW was indicted
for stealing, on the 17th of April, 1 cigar-case, value 2s.; and 4 cigars, 1s.; the goods of a certain man un
known, from his person.

WSILLIAMS GUEST (police-constable L 62.) I was at Greenwich fair on the 17th of April, and saw the prisoner following two-gentlemen—he thrust his hand into the coat pocket of one of them, and for a moment I lost sight of him—Brooks caught hold of him, and I saw this cigar-case partly in the pri
soner's hand, and partly in the officer's.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Is this the only case you have bad this session from Greenwich fair? A. Yes, and the first case I have had where the property has been taken from, a person unknown—I lost sight of the prisoner for about a second in the crowd—I spoke to both gentlemen, and they came with me to a coffee shop.

COURT. Q. Did you request the gentleman to go to the station? A. Yes, he said he would at first, but he was advised by his friend not to do so, as it would take some time—we requested him to give his name, and he re
fused to do it.

JAMES BROOK (police-constable L 118.) I was with Guest—I saw the pri
soner put his hand into a gentleman's pocket, and take out this cigar-case—I put my arms in front of him, took it from him, and the lid of it fell on the ground.
Cross-examined. Q. Was there a crowd? A. Yes, a large crowd—I did not lose sight of the prisoner for a moment—I was close by Guest, and I drew his attention to it.
COURT. Q. How came the gentleman not to go to the station? A. It is such a great distance from the fair.

GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Confined Six Months.

1686.
DANIEL GRIFFITH was indicted
for stealing, on the 5th of May, 1 pair of trowsers, value 5s., the goods of
Henry Dumford; and that he had been before convicted of felony; to which he pleaded

GUILTY .—
Transported for Seven Years.

1687.
RICHARD WELHAM and
WILLIAM CONNOR were indicted for
uttering counterfeit coin.

JAMES HOWORTH . I am in the Royal Marines, at Woolwich, and am em
ployed in the barber's shop there. On the 31st of March, Welham came to be shaved—I asked him for the money which he owed me—he said he had not got any, only sham money—he produced two half-sovereigns to me out of his purse, where I saw he had ten or a dozen more—he gave me two, and told me to keep them till he came again; not to part with them, or he would never pay me what he owed me—he was immediately called away by the corporal, and I put the half-sovereigns in a piece of paper into my pocket, and when Suttle came I gave them to him.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Where did you put them? A. In a cupboard, under lock and key—they remained there some days—the police
man came about three weeks alter—my mate has got a key to the place as well as me.
WILLIAM INGLISH . I am a private in the Royal Marines—I have a key to this cupboard—I did not take any half-sovereigns out—I never saw them.
WILLIAM SUTTLE (police-constable R 260.) I received these two half-sovereigns from Howorth.

ANN SONNEX . I am the wife of John Sonnex, who keeps the Duke on Horseback, in High-street, Woolwich. On the 11th of April I saw my hus
band clear the till of all the gold coin—there was none left in the till—Con
nor was employed in waiting in the house as an extra hand during the fair. Between four and five o'clock in the evening of the 13th of April, Welham came in—he asked for half a pint of rum, which came to 1s.—I put it on the counter—Connor ordered it—Welham came up, and said to Connor, "Bill, is this for me? "Connor said, "Yes, Dick"—Welham said, "Here, take this half-sovereign, "and Connor took it from him, and gave it to me—I gave 9s. in change to Connor, and he gave it to Welham—I put the half-sovereign into a bowl in the till—there was no other half-sovereign there—when we closed for the night, I took the coin out of the bowl and put it into a bag—there was no other half-sovereign but that, and I took it up stairs—on the 14th of April Welham came again in the evening—it was his general practice to come of an evening—he was in and out a good deal that day, and treating persons with liquor—he asked me for half-a-pint of gin-and-raspberry, which came to 8d.—I served him—he gave me a half-sovereign, and I gave him 9s. 4d. change—Connor stood by, but bad nothing to do with the change—in the course of that night Connor came for a pot of beer, and gave me a half-sovereign—he said it was for Dick, the marine—I gave him the change, and saw him give it to Welham in the passage—Welham said, "It is all right, Bill, you shall never want a shilling while I have one"—on Saturday, the 15th, Welham came again—in the course of that evening I took two half-sovereigns from Connor—he said they were from Dick, the marine—on the 16th Welham came again with a young woman—he gave me a half-sovereign, and I gave him 9s. 6d. change—Welham and Connor were always together—that even
ing Welham proposed to leave a half-sovereign with Connor, wrapped up in paper—Connor said, "Leave it at the bar, I will have nothing to do with

your money"—Welham said, "Give me my money, I am quite capable of taking care of my own money"—I gave it him back—I said, "Richard, your money is all half-sovereigns"—he said, "Yes, my sister, who keeps the Cricketers, lets me have half-a-sovereign a-day, or sometimes two, according as I can get her in a good humour"—on the Monday I received a half-sove
reign from Connor—I said it had two or three black specks on the head of it—he said he did not know anything about it, that it belonged to the ma
rine, and that he changed all the half-sovereigns—on Tuesday I received two half-sovereigns from Connor—I saw him give the change to Welham—in the evening of that day I received a half-sovereign from Welham, and he asked me to let Connor go with him to Greenwich fair—I refused, as my husband was not at home—Connor afterwards asked my husband's leave to go—he said he was no servant of bis, be might go where he pleased—he went, and I saw no more of him till the next day—during the whole of this time I did not receive a half-sovereign from any other person—they were all placed in a bowl, and put into the bag at night, and put into the desk, and carried down in the morning—on the 20th of April I looked to my money—I was going to count it—I saw the thirteen half-sovereigns, and it struck me they were different to the sovereigns, and among them was the one with black specks—my husband weighed them, and examined them, and found them bad—I then communicated with the police—Palmer came, and the half-sovereigns were all marked in his presence, and given to him—these now produced are them.

Cross-examined. Q. When was it you received the last? A. On Easter Tuesday—I only serve in the evening—my husband does in the day—we never allow our servants to serve—my husband puts money into the bowl as well as I—there were no half-sovereigns put into the bowl but what I put in—it was Connor's duty to hand the half-sovereigas from Welham to me, and the change to Welham.
JOHN SONNEX . I am husband to Ann Sonnex.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you receive any half-sovereigns from this Thurs
day to the Tuesday? A. None—I serve in the morning—I did not change a half-sovereign for anybody—I had not the key of the desk—my wife serves in the evening, and day time too—I have other business to attend to—I do hot serve above an hour every day.

EDWARD PALMER (police-constable R 231.) On the 20th of April I went to Mr. Sonnex—some half-sovereigns were produced—Mrs. Sonnex marked them, and they were given to me—these are them—I took Connor—he said, he knew nothing about it, he took the money from Dick, the marine—I af
terwards apprehended Welham—I told him it was for passing bad money—I put him into a coach, and when we were half-way, he said, "Have you ap
prehended me for passing bad half-sovereigns? "—I said, "Yes, "and he im
mediately went into a fit.

GEORGE HORSLEY . I keep the Cricketers—my wife is no relation of Wel
ham's—she could not, as his sister, have given him half-sovereigns occasion
ally.

MR. JOHN FIELD . I am inspector of coin to the Mint—I have examined all these coins—they are all counterfeit half-sovereigns—they have all been struck from one die—the two black marks on this one arise from the gilt having been worn off, and the base metal appearing underneath—the general appearance of them is tolerably good—they are made of brass—they will not ring.

WELHAM—
GUILTY . Aged 24.—
Confined Two Years.

CONNOR—
GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Confined Six Months.

1688.
MARTHA ROGERS was indicted
for stealing, on the 20th of April, 1 sixpence, and 9 groats; the monies of
William Hollands, her master.

WILLIAM HOLLANDS . I am clerk to Jones, Loyd, and Co., and live it Beresford-street, Newington—the prisoner was eight days in my service—in consequence of some suspicion, I marked some fourpenny pieces, and other silver, put it into my wife's purse, which I put into her reticule, and left it on the parlour table, as we were in the habit of doing—I locked the par
lour door and the key was put on the prisoner's mantel-piece for her to get the room ready in the morning—next morning I found the reticule lying on the table as usual, but missed some fourpenny pieces and a 6d.—I sent for a constable, and gave the prisoner in charge.
JOHN HUNTLEY (police-constable P 143.) I took the prisoner in custody, and took her to the station.

SARAH EVEREST . I am the wife of David Everest, a policeman, and live at the station—I searched the prisoner on the 20th of April, and found on her these nine fourpenny-pieces, a fivepenny-piece, another small piece, and a sixpence.
MR. HOLLANDS re-examined. These are what I marked, and put into the purse.

Prisoner. I had some clothes in pawn, which I was very much in want of, and seeing the bag lying on the table three or four days, I was tempted to take the money, which I should not have done, if it had not been lying there.

p.rs: GUILTY. Aged 17.—Recommended to mercy by the prosecutor.—

div1.p:
1689.
WILLIAM GOY was indicted
for stealing, on the 17th of Dec., 2 pewter pots, value 2s.; the goods of
Thomas Roberts.

CHARLES MILLER . I live in St. Ann's-street, Kennington—the prisoner was in my employ, as a chimney-sweeper, about seven months—in conse
quence of something I heard, I said, "William, where are those pots? "—he went to the soot yard, and brought three or four, such as publicans use—I asked how he came by them—he said they came from No. 4, Bedford-terrace—I asked what he was going to do with them—he said, "I do not know;" and then said, smilingly, "To sell them"—I said, "Are you aware what you are about to do? you are liable to be sent to Brixton; do you know who they belong to? "—he said "No"—I said, "You can read what is on them"—I could read it—one part over the inscription had been cleaned—on the 27th of April, a lad in my employ, named Lovejoy, brought me two pint pots—I gave information to the police that afternoon, and gave him the two pots—the others could not be found—I had asked the prisoner if he had taken the pots back—he said he had—I asked what the people said—he said, "Nothing"—I asked what they gave him—he said, "Only something to drink."

WILLIAM LOVE JOY . I live with Mr. Miller—I saw two pewter pots on the window-ledge of the soot-shed, about four months ago—I heard master tell the prisoner to take them home—he did not say where he was to take them—I saw them that same afternoon wrapped up in a handkerchief—last Thurs
day week, in cleaning out the loft, I found the same two pots under the tiles—I took them to my roaster—these are the pots.
THOMAS ROBERTS . I keep the Bedford Arms public-house, Clapham Rise—these two pots are mine—they were sent out to a customer—I cannot say
when they were at my house—I never saw the prisoner till he was at the office.
JOHN MENNIE . I am a policeman. On Thursday last I was sent for to Mr. Miller's house, and received these two pots.

WILLIAM ERMED . I am a policeman. I apprehended the prisoner—as I took him to the station, he said to a person that walked by his side, that he went to sweep a chimney on the terrace, and, in potting the soot into the bag, a pint pot fell out of his shovel, and he had picked up one previously; that the servant took it up and put it into his bag—he said he did not take it back, as his master told him, in consequence of his old mistress telling him not to do it.

Prisoner's Defence. I went to No. 4, Bedford-terrace, to sweep the kitchen chimneys. The stove was loose, and behind it I found this pot, which is burnt at the bottom, a coffee-pot, and a lot of old saucepan lids. I put them on one side; and as I was putting the soot into the sack, this other pot fell off the shovel; the servant picked it up, and put it into my sack. I did not see them till the soot was sifted, after I got home. I showed them to my master, who told me to take them home; but my mistress told me not to do so, but to leave them there, or throw them away. I left them in the top room. I left my master about six weeks ago, and set up for myself, and have got a few of his customers from him, and this is his spite. He knew the pots were in the house.
NOT GUILTY .

1690.
JOHN HARLEY was indicted
for breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
James Beswick, on the 24th of Dec., and stealing therein, 1 coat, value 1l. 10s.; 4 pairs of trowsers, 3l. 5s.; 4 waistcoats, 2l.; 1 pair of breeches, 15s.; 1 cloak, 1l.; 1 jacket, 5s.; 5 handkerchiefs, 12s.; 1 shawl, 15s.; 2 gowns, 15s.; and 1 petticoat, 2s.; his property.

JAMES BESWICK . I am a lead merchant, and live at No. 97, St. George's-row, Southwark. On Saturday, the 24th of Dec, I left my house, about a qaarter before nine o'clock, leaving no one in it—I double-locked the street-door, and fastened the windows all perfectly safe—I returned about a quarter past nine, with my wife—I found the door on the single lock, but still shut and fastened—I went in, and found the kitchen-door open, and a quantity of lucifer matches lying about—in my bed-room I found a plate-drawer had been opened, and missed the articles stated—the trowsers now produced were in the drawer of a bureau—I went with Lupton to a house in Lock's-fields, and there found a large bundle, containing these trowsers, breeches, and waistcoat, which are mine—I saw three children in bed there.

Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. I believe you prosecuted three par
ties, named Guilday, in Jan. last, for this robbery, and they were all con
victed? A. Yes—I did not see the prisoner at the house in Lock's-fields.

HENRY LUPTON (police-sergeant L 7.) On the night of the 24th of Dec. last I went to No. 9, York-street, Lock's-fields, from information I received—I did not find the prisoner there—three persons, named Guilday, were after
wards taken into custody—they were not there when I went—there were only four rooms in the house—I knocked at the street-door, an elderly woman opened it—I found these things in the front room up stairs, in the bed, covered over with the bed-clothes—three children were in the bed—the room-door was locked.
Cross-examined. Q. When you went to this house, did you find any of the Guildays there? A. The boy James Guilday, who was convicted in Jan.

last—I did not apprehend the others—they were taken about two hours and a half after—I first went into the room, on the ground floor—I found no pro
perty there—it was with the key of the back room ground floor that I opened the prisoner's room—I inquired for the key of the room, of the woman down stairs, and she said she knew nothing of it—the children were the prisoner's children—the bundle was in the bed, between the two sheets.

ELIZA TOOMEY . I am the wife of Daniel Toomey, and live at No. 9, York-street, Lock's-fields. The prisoner occupied the front room up stairs at the time of the robbery—he had three children—on Christmas eve I saw the prisoner go out at two o'clock in the day—I went out at eight, and did not return again till near twelve—the three Guildays were then in charge—they lived on the ground floor.
Cross-examined. Q. You have seen the prisoner in company with the Guildays in the house? A. Yes, talking to them, as I might do.

THOMAS TURVEY (police-constable M 196.) I took the prisoner into cus
tody in a public-house in the Borough—I told him he was wanted for the same case as the Guildays—he said, very well, he would go.
NOT GUILTY .

1691.
LUCY SHAW was indicted
for feloniously and knowingly uttering, on the 13th of March, a forged acquittance and receipt for 11d., with intent to defraud
John Smith.

JOHN SMITH. I am curator of the Royal Botanic Gardens at Kew. The prisoner was my servant—she had money to pay bills, and among the rest was this one of 11d.—she told me she had paid it, and brought me this as a re
ceipt, purporting to come from Mrs. Burbidge—I paid my bills on Tuesday—I afterwards found this out, went down stairs, and charged her with forging the name of Mrs. Burbidge—she made no denial—she put a paper into my hand, and said it would all be settled—I gave her in charge—she has put, "Paid, S. Burbidge."
Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. Did she not say she was very sorry, but intended to pay them? A. Yes.

SARAH BURBIDGE . I supply milk to Mr. Smith—on the 13th of March I had a bill against him of 1s. 2d. for milk—I have never received that—the signature to this bill is not mine, nor to this one of the 6th of March—I never received that money.

Cross-examined. Q. Did she tell you she had been in a great deal of trouble with her husband? A. Yes, and had kept back the money Mr. Smith had paid her to prevent his going to prison—she afterwards said that Mr. Smith's daughter would come and pay the last two weeks' bills, and that her brother was coming to settle every thing.
JAMES WILLIAM BURBIDGE . I am son of last witness—I never received this 11d. from the prisoner or Mr. Smith—nobody else receives money for my mother.

----.
