I am the prisoner's brother—her husband is a waiter, and he has been out of employment some time—her children have been ill, and two are dead—I offered to pay every farthing of this—she applied to me on the Sunday after she left the prosecutor, and before she was charged with this offence, and I promised to see into it on the Monday or Tuesday—I never knew a blemish on her character.
MR. SMITH re-examined. She was first charged with this on the 10th of April.
NOT GUILTY .

1692.
LUCY SHAW was again indicted
for knowingly uttering a forged receipt for 1s. 2d. on the 20th of March, with intent to defraud
John Smith.

JOHN SMITH . I had weekly bills with Mrs. Burbidge for milk—on the 13th of March I owed her 1s. 2d.—the prisoner brought me this bill as re
ceipted by Mrs. Burbidge.

SARAH BURBIDGE . This is not my writing—I never received the 1s. 2d.—before the prisoner was charged at all she came and told me that her brother was coming to settle every thing, and my bills should be paid.
Cross-examined. Q. Did she appoint to call on you on the Sunday? A. On the Saturday night—she did not come—she sent me word on the Monday that her brother was coming.
JAMES WILLIAM BURBIDGE . I have not received the 1s. 2d.—I know nothing of this writing.
FRANCES CREED . I found these other bills on the prisoner at the station.
NOT GUILTY .

1693.
THOMAS WREN, alias Maryon
, was indicted
for rape.
NOT GUILTY .

1694.
THOMAS WHITE,
THOMAS ALLISON,
SARAH JONES , and
SARAH FULLER , were indicted for
burglariously breaking and enter
ing the dwelling-house of
Elizabeth Hackett, about twelve in the night of the 9th of April, at
St. John, Southwark, with intent to steal, and stealing therein, 24 shirts, value 2l. 8s., and 10 pairs of trowsers, 7l., her property; and that White had been before convicted of felony.

ELIZABETH HACKETT . I am single, and keep a slop-shop in Thornton-street, Dockhead, in the parish of St. John. On Sunday night, the 9th of April, I went to bed at eleven o'clock—the house was all safe—just before twelve I heard a great noise, got up, opened the window, but could see no
body but a woman at the top of the alley—I went down about seven in the morning, found the fan-light over the door broken right in, sufficiently for a person to get into the house—a bundle of shirts was taken away, and ten pairs of trowsers, worth 9l. 12s. 6d.

GEORGE GALE . I sell coffee and ginger-beer, and live in Brewer's-court, Horsleydown, in the next street to the prosecutrix—I saw the four prisoners that night, a little after four o'clock, with another not in custody, in Thorn
ton-street,—they passed by me—they had nothing with them that I saw—I asked them if they wanted any coffee or ginger-beer—White made some re
mark and they went on about twenty yards, then stopped for about five minutes, and seemed to be considering—they came back—I had a cane on my truck—White took it up—I told him to put it down, it was not his pro
perty—we had a tustle to get it—then Allison came back to him, and said something—I thought I heard they should be blown or something, and he gave me the cane, they all five went on, and turned into New-street, which is at the back of Thornton-street—in ten minutes or a quarter of an hour I saw them come into an alley—White came forward, and seemed to be talking to somebody behind—they stood there some time, went back, and appeared to go into New-street, into Thornton-street—the female prisoners went and stood by the post-office, about 100 yards from the prosecutrix's—the male prisoners came up the street—Allison went down a court by the side of the house, and then White went down—I went towards the place, to see what they were doing—the male prisoners crossed the road, and went down towards the females, and the man not in custody walked down on the same side of the way as the prosecutrix's shop—that was the last I saw of them till I saw
the women in custody that evening, and White and Allison on the Saturday following.
Allison. I was not before the Magistrate. Witness. No, he was not—I never knew any of them before.

THOMAS TURVEY . I am a policeman. On Monday morning, the 10th of April, about nine o'clock, I was going on duty on Southwark-bridge-road—I saw all the prisoners and one not in custody in company—the two females had something in both their aprons—I asked them what they had—they said, "Some work"—I asked where they got it from—Fuller said her sister was in the habit of taking out work from a slop-shop, and they were going to take it home to their sister—I asked what they had to do to them, or if they were finished—they could not tell me—I asked them to let me look at them, which I did, and asked where their sister lived—they said a little way along the street, that is Norfolk-street—I said I would go with them—the men went on, and when they found I detained the women they all three ran away—I took the women to the station—in a few minutes after the prosecutrix came to give information of her shop being broken open and property stolen—she claimed the property—I had seen the three men frequently before—I am sure White and Allison are two of them.

White. I was forty yards from the females when you stopped them. Witness. He was not further than I am from him now—they were all five together—I had followed them nearly 150 yards—they were talking till they saw me close on them, and then the men made away from the women.
MRS. HACKETT re-examined. This is part of the property I lost—I know the shirts by the make, as well as by a particular mark in the cotton, which I noticed when I had them.

White's Defence. I met the two females on the other side of London-bridge; they asked me to give them something to drink; I said yes, if they came to the house I would. We went and had three or four pots of beer together; they asked me to give them a breakfast, which I did, at eight o'clock. I then said, "I must go to my work." I had got a little way along Southwark-bridge-road, and saw them coming after me. I afterwards looked behind, and saw them with the policemen I met two strange men in the street; this was not one.

Jones's Defence. On Sunday night a young woman who I knew asked me to mind the shirts for her; she must pawn them on Monday morning; she said she was taking them to her sister's; the policeman has told a great story.
Allison's Defence. I can prove where I was at the time the robbery was committed, but have not had time. I had nothing to do with the robbery.

WILLIAM KEATING . I am a policeman. I produce a certificate of White's former conviction, from the office of the Clerk of the Peace for Surrey—(read)—I was present at the trial—he is the man—he was tried by the name of John Smith.

WHITE—
GUILTY . * Aged 22.—
Transported for Life.

ALLISON—
GUILTY .

JONES—
GUILTY . Aged 20.

FULLER—
GUILTY . Aged 17.

1695.
DAVID BOYD was indicted
for stealing, on the 6th of May, at
St. John, Southwark, 10 watches, value 8l.; 2 watch-cases, 1l.; 1 time
piece, 12s.; 1 coat, 15s.; 1 handkerchief, 2s. 6d.; 10 seals, 4l.; 10 watch
keys, 2l. 10s.; 3 split rings, 12s.; 4 watch-chains, 4s.; and 2 watch-guards, 4s.; the goods of
Samuel Nicholas, in his dwelling-house.
MARIA DANIELS . I am the wife of John Daniels, and lodge at the house of Mr. Nicholas. Last Sunday morning I awoke between six and seven o'clock,

and saw my door open—I then looked on the floor, and saw him—his head was under the bed—I jumped out of bed, took hold of the prisoner by the collar, and asked what he was doing there—he said he had been there all night—I gave an alarm, Mr. Nicholas came and took him till a policeman came—I went down into the yard, and found the back-door open—I found a bundle in a washing-tub there—I gave it to Mr. Nicholas.

SAMUEL NICHOLAS . I am a watch and clock maker, and live in Tooley-street, in the parish of St. John, Southwark. I fastened up my house at night, and went to bed a little before twelve o'clock—I was called in the morning, between six and seven, by Mrs. Daniels—I came down, and found the pri
soner in her room, on his knees—I took charge of him, and sent for a police
man, who came, searched him in my presence, and produced several gold keys and gold seals, and various other things, which I knew to be say property—the bundle which Mrs. Daniels produced was opened in my presence, and con
tained a coat, ten watches, and other property—the value of all the property is 20l. or more—the house was not broken into—I suppose he must have secreted himself in the shop over night—all the property now produced is mine, and was in my shop the night before.
DANIEL CARROLL . I am a policeman. These things have been in my care ever since.
Prisoner's Defence. I was walking down Tooley-street; I had no place to sleep in; I saw the door of this house open, and went in, having nowhere to go.

GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Transported for Ten Years.

1696.
WILLIAM WHEELWRIGHT and
MICHAEL KIDNEY were indicted for
burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
John Tilleard, about one in the night of the 12th of August, at St. George-the-Martyr, Southwark, with intent to steal.

JOHN HENRY TILLEARD . I am the son of John Tilleard, an oil and co
lourman, in Great Suffolk-street, St. George-the-Martyr, Southwark. On Tuesday night, the 11th of April, I closed the shop, and saw the premises safe—between one and two o'clock in the morning, I was aroused by the police—I found the sash of the door leading into the shop, forced—it had been safe overnight—there were marks on the door of some instrument having been used to force it.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Was it broken sufficient for a person to get in? A. Yes—the marks were on the middle door—the sash and shatter of the outer door were forced open.

FREDERICK LICHFIELD . I am a policeman. On the morning of the 12th of April, between one and two o'clock, I was in Great Suffolk-street—from information I received I hastened to the prosecutor's house—I saw both the prisoners there—Wheelwright had just come from the inside him
self, and seeing me, he called out to somebody inside, "Look out, look out!"—I was within two paces of him—he ran across the street—I collared another, as he came out of the door, but he got away—Kidney followed that second man as he came out—he had no hat or cap on—the three attacked me, and prevented my sounding my rattle—they knocked it all to pieces, and sprained my hand—I knew them by sight before—I distinctly saw their faces—I saw the prisoners in custody next day, and knew them—I examined the door, and saw marks of a jemmy on it—I found this jemmy a few yards from the door—there were marks on the sash of the door, corresponding with this.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Did the person you say was Kidney come out close to the one you held by the collar? A. He did—I cannot
say how I was knocked down—I was tripped up from behind—I gave a description of the men—I have not the least doubt of them—I should know the third man.

Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. You were a few paces from the door when Wheelwright appeared at it? A. About two paces—Wheelwright ran across the way, calling out to those inside, "Look out, look out!"—I never saw him again till he was in custody—Kidney came out within a minute or so after Wheelwright—he did not run away at the instant.

BENJAMIN PARSONS . I am a policeman. I took the two prisoners into custody on Thursday, the 13th of April, between three and four o'clock in the morning, at their lodging in Kent-street, both in the same house—they denied all knowledge of it.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Did they deny all knowledge of the burglary? A. They did—they heard the charge at the station, and did not deny it in my presence—they denied it at their lodging, not at the station—I did not say, "From a description I have received I must take you, and mean to swear to you right or wrong"—Lichfield the constable, the inspector, and two or three more constables were present—I said nothing of the sort to either of them—tbe burglary was on the 11th—I took them on the 13th.

JAMES HARRISON (police-constable M 195.) I know the prisoners by sight. On the night of the 11th of February, about a quarter past twelve, I saw them in Great Suffolk-street—Kidney was standing alone, about 40 yards from Wheelwright and Bevan, who is not in custody—about a quarter after one o'clock I saw Kidney standing in the doorway of a fishmonger's shop about forty yards from Mr. Tilleard's—I knew their persons, and was perfectly well acquainted with them.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Did you speak to either of them? A. I did not—I crossed over from the opposite side, and passed them—when I saw Kidney in the fishmonger's door-way, I was on the same side of the way—he shammed drunkenness when he saw me, and reeled across the road—I had seen him not an hour before, and he could walk very well then.

Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. Did you tell Parsons you had seen them? A. I did not, I did not see him till we went to Union-hall on the Thursday—I told Parsons then that they were the parties who I had seen loitering about, one had a hat on, and the other two caps.

COURT. Q. How was it they did not get any goods from the house? A. They had not time—I had seen my sergeant shortly before—I heard my bro
ther constable call out "Stop thief"—I ran up, but they had escaped.

FREDERICK LITCHFIELD
re-examined. This hat dropped off the man not in custody, in the struggle, and this cap was found in the shop—Kidney always wore a cap of this description, and he had a similar one on when apprehended, but perfectly new.
JURY. Q. What enabled you to see the parties so well? A. From the gas-light which was within a few yards of the door.

JAMES HARRISON
re-examined. When I saw them before the robbery, one had a hat, and two had caps—Kidney had a cap of this description.

WHEELWRIGHT—
GUILTY . Aged 21.

KIDNEY—
GUILTY . Aged 20.

1697.
WILLIAM HOLMES was indicted
for bigamy.

JANE HEDGES . I am the wife of William Hedges, of Hampton; I have known the prisoner more than twenty years. In the autumn of 1829 I was present, at Teddington church, Middlesex, when he was married by banns to Maria Budd—she was about 22 or 23 years of age—I have seen her

to-day—I have known many marriages solemnized at Teddington church—Mr. Hoare was the clergyman officiating at the time—they lived together afterwards as man and wife for about nine months, very near me, at Hampton.

THOMAS WINCH (police-sergeant N 40.) I produce an examined copy of the register of marriage between William Holmes and Maria Budd in Oct., 1829—I got it from the first wife—I went to the parish church at Teddington, and examined it with the register, in the clerk's room at his private residence, where the books are kept—they are not kept at the church—when I went about the certificate of the second marriage the book was fetched from the church to the clerk's house for me to examine it by—I had never seen the clerk before—I went to the church; the people opposite told me I should find the clerk at the house, and he showed me the book—there are several blanks in this certificate—they were so in the register.

JANE HEDGES
re-examined. I knew the clergyman at the time—I know he was the officiating minister—he attended the church in his usual dress—it was before twelve o'clock.

WILLIAM GUNTON . I am a carpenter and joiner, and live at Kingston. I was occasionally employed as journeyman by the late William Turvey, who acted as parish clerk of Ham church—he was a master carpenter—I have known the prisoner eight or nine years—in 1840 I was at work at Turvey's house, and saw the prisoner and a woman named Harriet Talley, whom I knew before, go into Turvey's house; after remaining there some time they came out, and went with Turvey towards Ham parish church, which is about fifty yards from the house—I do not know whether they went into the church—they afterwards came back to the clerk's house, and went over to the Jolly Gardeners beer-shop.

JANE TALLEY . I live with my mother, Harriet Talley, in York-street, Rotherhithe. I have known the prisoner about twelve months—he and my mother lived as man and wife—they were so for aught I know—they used the same room.

THOMAS WINCH
re-examined. I produce a paper purporting to be an examined copy of a marriage in Ham church—I got it from the clerk's house—he professed to be the clerk of Ham church—I do not know whether he was to—he showed me a book—I examined this copy with it—the clerk is since dead—he was one of the attesting witnesses to the marriage.

ELIZABETH NYE . I am a pew-opener at Ham parish church. Mar
riages are celebrated there, and have been so for many years—it was first a chapel, but is consecrated as a church—I have been pew-opener there nine years—I was present, in August, 1840, at a marriage between William Holmes and Harriet Talley—I cannot recognize the prisoner—there was some little dif
ficulty in putting the ring on the bride's finger, but I did not see what it was—it was put on the left hand—the bride had on a dress of the clerk's daughter—the party went from the church to the clerk's house, and then to the Jolly Gardeners—I recollect hearing the banns put up three successive Sundays in the names of William Holmes and Harriet Talley—the Rev. James Hough is the clergyman who married them—the clerk is since dead—I did not know Talley before her marriage, and did not know her name, or whether she was single or a widow—she was described as a widow, and was asked in church by the name of Harriet Talley—I recollect that—the registers are usually kept in an iron chest in the vestry; but the clerk being very ill in bed, and not able to get up, and the clergyman being from home, they might be sent for to his house.
AMELIA SNOW . I am the wife of William Snow, and live in Lower Queen-street, Rotherhithe. I have known the prisoner eighteen years—he came to

live in the neighbourhood two years and a half ago, and introduced a person as his wife—I had not seen him for fifteen years before that—the woman wore a ring on her right hand—I asked why she did not wear it on her left—she said she could not, as she had two fingers joined together—I did not know her name before—I never knew her as Harriet Talley.
NOT GUILTY .

1698.
WILLIAM MELLISH was indicted
for obtaining 2s. 6d. from
William Till by false pretences; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined One Month.

1699.
REBECCA RUMBALL was indicted
for feloniously forcing, cast
ing, and throwing
Isaac Rumball into the water of a certain canal, with intent to kill and murder him.—2nd COUNT, stating it to be a male child of hers called Isaac.

RICHARD HEATH . I am a policeman. On Sunday, the 2nd of April, about ten o'clock in the evening, I saw the prisoner in Peckham-fields, north from Taylor's-bridge to Box-bridge—she was on the side footpath, crossing the fields, a very few yards from the canal—I said nothing to her then—I met her a second time, and said, "Good night, ma'am"—she said, "Good night, sir, good night"—she had a child at her breast—after she had passed me about five or ten minutes I heard some gentleman hallooing—I listened a moment, ran back, and when I got up the gentleman told me he thought there was somebody in the water—I turned my light on the water, and found a female there—I sang out for the drag, which was brought—I threw it in three times, and Ulrick got a boat and reached her—I and Taylor went over the other side of the canal, and pulled out the prisoner with a child lashed to her with this string—they both appeared to be dead—we took them into George Taylor's—a surgeon was sent for—they had recovered before the surgeon came—the string was tied round the child's neck, and two or three times round the prisoner's left arm.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. When you said "Good night," she said "Good night, sir," did she say it in a hurried distracted manner? A. No—she was walking rather fast—she did not appear to answer me quickly—the child was a boy—it was a gentleman named Sparks who first gave the alarm—he is not here—she could have been but a short time in the water.

HENRY ULRICK . On the 2nd of April I heard an alarm given—I got a boat and took the prisoner out of the water with a child—there was a string round its neck and round the prisoner's waist and left wrist.

GEORGE TAYLOR . On the 2nd of April, I heard an alarm, and assisted in carrying the prisoner in—she is my sister-in-law—there was a child with her—it was her own—its name is Isaac Rumball—I am acquainted with the Humane Society—I used the proper methods to bring her and the child to life—they both recovered.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you know who she was when she was first brought out of the water? A. Not at first—it took about a quarter of an hour, or twenty minutes to recover her—the child was recovered in less than five minutes—from the position the child was found in, it would float above her—she is in the family way now—I did not know the father of the child—she has always been a kind affectionate creature—I never saw her otherwise—she is not married—she is 23, 24, or 25 years of age—her mother always kept the child—she is without any means of her own—she was in service at Stam
ford-hill—she was not going to leave—I was in the house when she threw herself into the water, and did not hear any splash.
COURT. Q. Where was she when you first saw her? A. By the side of the second bridge in the fields—I had helped my young man to take her out—I first saw her in the water.

THOMAS TRUNCHEON . On Sunday night, the 2nd of April, at a quarter to eleven o'clock, I found an umbrella and bag, containing two letters, about three yards from where the body was found, about three yards from the canal side—I delivered them to Day, the policeman—I saw them in Day's hands the next morning, and saw him give them to Taylor.

GEORGE TAYLOR
re-examined. I have the umbrella and the bag, with the two letters in it—I believe they are the prisoner's handwriting; but can only swear to my belief—I have seen her write many times—the last time was three or four yean ago—I never saw her sign her name.

COURT. Q. Have you looked at the letters? A. Yes; there is some re
semblance to her handwriting, but I cannot say.

ELIZA RUMBALL . I am the prisoner's sister—this is her bag—the letters are like her writing—I should not like to swear they are her's—I believe them to be so from the appearance—I have seen her write, and believe they are her's.

Cross-examined. Q. When did you last see her write? A. Since she has been in Newgate, some writing that came from her—I believe it was her writing—I have never seen much of her writing—I should not like to sweat that they are her's—I believe it to be her's—(read.)

"Mr. Taylor, Waterford Arms, Peckham: Ist April. Dear Ann and George,—I hope you will forgive me for all my past folly, and do the best you can with me with regard to bury me. I have a long time thought of this unhappy death. I see there is nothing but trouble for me, and happi
ness for others. Your unworthy sister—REBECCA RUMBALL."

"Stamford-hill. Dear mother and sisters,—I own I am very much in
debted to you. I have brought on you an expense which is growing heavy on you. You were kind enough to say you would take him home; I have been thinking there will be much jealousy in your doing so, so I think of ending our lives in the canal, which I hope if George will not see us when alive, he will see us when dead, and hope you will bury us both together, me and my darling boy. I hope you and all my friends will pardon my sins. I am praying, and trying to seek repose in the bosom of God, which I have in vain sought for on earth; my own folly has brought me to this unhappy death. I hope you will think no more of me, but pray that my sins may be forgiven me, and that we may meet again in the next world. I hope you will forgive me. I hope you will all live happy together, my dear sister, you and George. Your dutiful daughter—REBECCA RUMBALL."

ELIZA RUMBALL
Cross-examined. Q. Who is meant by George? A. My brother-in-law—he had not refused to set her—the prisoner was very fond of the child—it is three years old, and is very fond of her—the father is dead—she has not had much trouble—she did what she could to support the child with her wages.

GUILTY. Aged 24.—Strongly recommended to mercy. —
Confined Two Years.

1700.
ANN HODGKISS was indicted
for stealing, on the 21st of March, 1 snuff-box, value 3l.:—also, on the 8th of June, 2 tooth-brushes, 3s.; the goods of John Dawson, her master: to both which she pleaded

GUILTY . * Aged 31.—
Confined Twelve Months.

1701.
WILLIAM JAMES and
EDWARD JAMES were indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of May, 280lbs. weight of coals, value 2s. 6d.; the goods of
Robert Dalgleish and another, in a barge on the navigable river Thames: to which

WILLIAM JAMES pleaded
GUILTY . * Aged 49.—
Confined Six Months.

EDWARD JAMES pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined Three Months.

1702.
JAMES COATES was indicted
for stealing, on the 4th of Jan., 1 watch, value 6l.; the goods of
George William Deane and another, his masters.

GEORGE WILLIAM DEANE . I am in partnership with Thomas Winkley—we live in High-street, Borough, and are watchmakers. In Jan., 1842, I took the prisoner into our service in consequence of an advertisement, and fully approving of him, I raised his wages to 18s. a-week—he boarded and lodged in the house exactly as one of my family—on Sunday evening, the 20th of Nov., he was taken ill, and on the Monday morning he was not able to get up—about a fortnight before that, or between a fortnight and three weeks, I had put into his hands a French gold hunting-watch to have the upper case raised, that the works might be free of the glass—the cases should have been taken off the works—when I gave it to him, I said, "I have determined on having the case raised so that it may free the glass, I have determined not to go to further expense," and I think I said, "It shall go to Fielder, in St. John-street-road," but whether I did or not, he knew that, because he was the only person I employed for that purpose—he was to have sent it by a lad I keep for that purpose, and I should have expected it would have been ready in two or three days, for the boy to have called again for it—it was not necessary that the works should have gone with the case—the prisoner knew that, decidedly—he was taken ill on the 20th of Nov., and a day or two af
terwards I missed the movement of this watch—he was then very ill—I said nothing to him about it—he resumed his work on the 3rd of Jan., and on the following evening I brought him the whole of his work, which I had taken away from his work-board in the shop—I said to him, "Where is the French gold hunting watch, it is high time that was completed, and fit for stock?"—he said, "Bless me, sir, has not that French gold hunting-watch come home yet? why I sent it pretty nigh a month before I was taken ill; John took it"—I said, "Where to?"—he said, "To Jackson's"—I said, "Who is Jack
son, is he a respectable man?"—he said, "O yes, a perfectly respectable man; the watch is safe enough"—I said, "Where does he live?"—he said, "At the back of Clerkenwell prison"—I said, "Well, but how is it I don't see the movement of the watch amongst this work which I have delivered to you; there was no occasion for the movement to be away?"—he said, "That is with it"—I said, "For what purpose is the movement with; the case?"—he said, "O, sir, the movement was foul of the dome, it would not close"—I said, "Well, I shall send John after it in the morning"—it was then about six in the evening—he slept in the house that night, and the next morning he got up to assist the lad in opening the shop—I was uneasy, and got up as soon as he did—I was down in the shop some time, and then I went to break
fast, expecting him to follow me, but he did not come—I found he was gone, and never returned—he had never assigned any reason to me for going, but he seemed to be better that morning—I took some pains to find Mr. Jackson, and inquired at the back of Clerkenwell prison—I found the prisoner on the evening of the 12th of Jan., at No. 4, Victoria-place, Kent-road—after some other conversation, I said, "Now, where is the French gold hunting-watch?"—after some hesitation, he said, "At Mr. Carter's"—I said, "Where

does he live?"—he said, "In President-street"—I gave him in charge—on the following evening I went to Mr. Carter's, I there found the gold hunting-watch—Mr. Carter also produced to me this pencil memorandum, which is the handwriting of the prisoner—(read)—"New cover and dome—Deane and Co., 169, Borough"—the dome is the inner case which coven the move
ment, and the cover is this outer case which I had given instructions to have raised—the effect of putting a new cover and a new dome on this watch, would be that I should not know the watch myself—it would take away the maker's name and the number, and destroy the identity of the watch alto
gether—I had never given him the slightest authority for any such alteration—it was altogether unnecessary.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. It would make it like an English. watch? A. No—everybody knowing the nature of a watch would know was not English—the French name would be away—I first spoke to the prisoner on the 4th of January—he then said it was at Jackson's—he seemed very poorly, and I did not press him any further, intending to proceed the following day—he had the erisypelas in his head—Mr. Carter had repaired a watch at the end of December—I have at times given the prisoner returned watches to wear, which is a very common thing—he went away on the morn
ing of the 5th of January, and his sister afterwards brought back a gold watch that he had with him when he went away—I am not a regular watchmaker myself, but I have had the handling of them for twenty-five years.
MR. CLARKSON. Q. Have you been a housekeeper many years? A. Yes, and carried on business in this establishment, in which I was brought up.

JOHN MALYON . I am in the prosecutor's service—it is my business to carry out watches—I received this watch and another from the prisoner, to take to Mr. Fielder's, to inquire what it would come to to alter them—I took them, and brought them back, and told him Mr. Fielder said it would come to about 25s.—he never gave me this watch back to take to Fielder—I do not know Mr. Jackson living behind the new prison at Clerkenwell—I never took anything there for the prisoner.

WILLIAM CARTER . I am a watch-case maker, and live in President-street, St. Luke's. I never saw the prisoner till he was in custody—this watch was brought to me, as I understand, about two hours after the prisoner was in custody—I think it was on the 12th of January—this written memo
randum came with it—it was delivered at my street-door, to the servant girl, and brought up to me—I had no other direction than what this memorandum contains—Mr. Deane called on me the following day, and I produced to him the watch and the memorandum—I saw no necessity for a new dome, and I delayed doing it, and was going to Mr. Deane, though I did not know him, and have never, to my knowledge, done but one job for him—in order to raise the case to hold the glass, there was no necessity for a new dome—it would have destroyed the identity of the watch altogether—the movement is quite free of the dome.

WILLIAM LEVER (police-constable P 119.) I took the prisoner on the 12th of January—he was discharged by the Magistrate—on the 1st of March I took him again on another charge—(memorandum read)—"New cover and dome. Deane and Co., 169, Borough."
NOT GUILTY .

1703.
JAMES COATES was again indicted
for stealing, on the 3rd of January, 5 purse tassels, value 4s.; three other purse tassels, 1s.; 1 pair of purse slides, 6d.; 5 shirt studs, 5s.; 1 snap, 1s. 6d.; and 1 ear-ring, 1s.; the goods of
George William Deane and another, his masters.

GEORGE WILLIAM DEANE . In consequence of the absence of the prisoner, I caused a box of his that was left behind to be opened by the constable—it was locked—I found in it these five silver shirt studs, a black ear-ring top, and some purse slides—the whole I do not think exceeding 10s. in value—I had never given the prisoner authority to take any portion of these articles—they are mine—some of them bear my own mark on them.

Prisoner. Q. What mark is on them? A. Here is a scratch, a private mark, which I believe you have no knowledge of—I had it before you were in my service—I can clearly see the marks on three out of five of these studs, and I have no doubt it is on the other two—this snap has my mark on it, and this black top—it is my custom to mark my goods—these silver studs are worth 1s. each—I cannot say that I actually missed them till they were found—I then went to the drawer, where I knew they were—I had placed the purse tassels in the drawer a short time previous.
THOMAS WINKLEY . I am in partnership with Mr. Deane. I never gave the prisoner permission to take these things—I have nothing to do with this business.

WILLIAM LEVER (police-constable 119 P.) I was called to examine the prisoner's box—it was locked—I opened it with a key which I took from the prisoner—I found these things in a small drawer in the box.
Prisoner. Q. Were they loose? A. Yes, I laid them on the beach before the Magistrate—he did not make any remark about them.
The prisoner called

CHARLOTTE COATES . I am the prisoner's sister. While he was in a state of unsound mind, Mrs. Deane had the key of his box—she kept it more than a week, because he was incapable of taking care of it—she said if he had the key he might take things out that would injure him—I saw her put the watch-guard, and rings, and several other things into the box.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. Were you living at Mrs. Deane's? A. No—I heard from her that she had the key of the box—when I wanted I used to ask her for it, and perhaps keep it all day—my brother has been in business for him
self—he went by the name of James Wright, in consequence of a disagree
ment between him and his father.
Prisoner. These things were given by Mrs. Deane to the children to play with—I deny any knowledge of them.

GUILTY . Aged 26.—
Confined One Year.

1704.
FREDERICK BROWN was indicted
for stealing, on the 21st of April, 1 basket, value 9d.; and 1 towel, 3d., the goods of
Edward Elliott; 1 loaf of bread, 3d.; and a 1/4 lb. weight of pork, 2d.; the goods of
John Toff Steadman.

JOHN TOFF STEADMAN . I am in the service of Mr. Edward Elliott, and drive his van. On the 28th of April, I had a basket with a cloth in it, and some bread and meat, and cheese—I saw the prisoner and another come out of the Bald-faced Stag at Putney, as I was coming by—the prisoner came up to the near side of the van, and took the basket off a hook—I told him it was mine—he ran away, and threw it over the bridge—he was about twenty yards off when I overtook him.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. You had other parcels of con
siderable value? A. Yes—I had not known the prisoner before, nor the other man—I charged the other man, because he and the prisoner were toge
ther I thought—I saw the prisoner take the basket—I do not know whether he knew I saw him—I was feeding my horses when he took it off—he did
not run away—he stood and swore at me—I had been walking on the near side of my van, and the basket was on the near side.

COURT. Q. How far had he got from the cart when you first noticed him with the basket? A. About twenty yards—when he took it he put it under his arm—the other man did nothing—the bread and the meat could not be seen.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY. Aged 24.—Recommended to mercy. —
Confined Fourteen Days.

1705.
GEORGE BERRYMAN was indicted
for embezzling 12s. 3d., which he had received for his master,
James Fricker; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 24.—
Confined One Year.

1706.
THOMAS ROGERS was indicted
for uttering counterfeit coin.

THOMAS FREEMAN . I am a licensed victualler. On the 12th of March, the prisoner came to my place for half a pint of porter—I served him—he gave me a bad shilling—I gave him into custody—I marked the shilling—there were two other persons there—I kept it on the bar till I had served him, but it was in my sight all the time.

WILLIAM DRODGE . I am a policeman. On the 12th of March I took the prisoner, and received this shilling from Freeman—the prisoner was dis
charged, there being no other case against him.

JOHN HOLDER . I keep the Crown and Thistle, in South-Lambeth. On the 16th of March the prisoner came for some ale—he gave me a half-crown—I gave him 2s. 4 1/2 d. change—I put the half-crown into the till—there was no other there—my wife soon called my attention to it, and I found it was bad—on the 30th of May the prisoner came again, and gave my wife a half-crown—I received it from her—I sent for an officer, and gave him in charge.

RHODA HOLDER . I am the wife of John Holder. On the 16th of March the prisoner called for a glass of ale—I after that called my husband's atten
tion to the half-crown I found in the till—on the 30th the prisoner called again for half a pint of porter, and gave me a bad half-crown—I gave it my husband.
JOHN MAURICE (police-constable V 70.) I took the prisoner on the 30th and received these two half-crowns from Mr. Holder—I only found a half-penny on the prisoner.
MR. JOHN FIELD . I am inspector of coin to the Mint. These two half-crowns are counterfeit, and this shilling is also counterfeit.

GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Confined Six Months.

1707.
JAMES PALLETT was indicted
for bigamy, to which he pleaded

GUILTY .—
Transported for Seven Years.

1708.
JOHN HERNE was indicted for
burglariously breaking and enter
ing the dwelling-house of
John Bennett, about the hour of two in the night of the 12th of April, at
Lambeth, with intent to steal, and stealing therein, 1 coat, value 10s.; 1 kettle, 6s.; 1 cloak, 2s.; 1 weighing-machine, 10s.; 3 pairs of shoes, 21s.; 1 candlestick, 2s.; 3lbs. weight of pork, 15d.; and 6lbs. weight of ham, 4s.; the goods of John Bennett; and
PHILIP ROW
LAND
for feloniously receiving the same, well-knowing it to have been stolen; against the Statute, &c.
JOHN BENNETT . I am a cow keeper, residing in North Brixton, in the

parish of St. Mary, Lambeth. On the evening of Wednesday, the 12th of April, I secured my house myself—the kitchen window fastens with a button inside—there is a dairy within my premises—I fastened the dairy-door up myself—I went to bed about eleven, leaving everything safe—be
tween two and three in the morning I thought I heard a bell ring—I got up, knocked against the door, and then went to bed again, hearing no answer—I got up as usual, about five, and went out to milk some cows—I did not examine my house—I got back about a quarter to six, and went to the dairy, which I had fastened the over night, and missed a side of pork, a sheep's tongue, and half a ham from there—from the kitchen I missed a cloak, a coat, a pair of scales, three pairs of shoes, a copper kettle, and a candlestick—I examined the kitchen window, and found it had been cut through by some instrument from outside, and cut the beading of the stop so as to come to the button—they had turned the button round, and a person had got in there—there was the print of the heels—the dairy-door was cut so that something could be put in, and push back the bolt—I was the first person that came down that morning, and the last that went to bed the night before—I have seen some of the property since—it is mine—it was safe in the house over night—it is worth 3l. or 4l.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Was the prisoner the police
man in your neighbourhood? A. No.

RICHARD LAMBURN (police-constable D 128.) On Thursday morning, the 13th of April, the day before Good Friday, between nine and ten, I was in bed—I had been out on night duty—my wife called me up to see Herne—he was in the police at that time—he said he knew of a cheap bargain of some things to be sold belonging to a poor man, and wanted me to go down and look at them—he said he thought I could have them cheap, as the poor man was hard up—he wanted 23s. for them, and he should not be surprised if I could have them for less—I was to go to No. 54, James-street, which is about half a mile from Mr. Bennett's—I had heard that Rowland lived there—I went to No. 54, James-street, and there found a Petersham coat and cloak, some scales, and two pairs of shoes—they have since been claimed by the prose
cutor—I left 23s. with Herne in case he could not get them for less-on Easter Monday he came down to my house with a boy, and brought the things—he told me he was going to take the boy to show him the races—he said he was obliged to give the 23s., and he left the things with me—they continued at my house till I gave them up to the officer—on the Wednesday Herne came again and told me he had been buying a candlestick cheap, he gave 6d. for it, and thought it was worth the money as old brass—he brought it down a day or two after—I told him I was going to take an iron boiler to Baalzephon-street, Bermondsey, and we took the copper kettle with it—we mentioned the brass candlestick, and a person who lived in Mrs. Edwards's house, said she wanted one, she came over to me the following Wednesday, and purchased it—I had given in my resignation, and was about going into business myself to buy and sell.

Cross-examined. Q. Are you in the police now? A. Yes—I have not been on duty since—I have not heard that I am suspended—I have been on this case—I did not hear anything of this till the 1st of May, and then I gave the things up to Sergeant Slack—I swear I was dealing with these articles, and other articles also—I had nine waistcoats, and some handkerchiefs, which I bought at Burlton's, a pawnbroker in the Walworth-road—I am going to set up a shop, to sell second-hand clothes—I was selling all sorts of articles—some of these things were sent down into the country—Herne and I were going into business together—I thought he was a straight-forward man, and we

were going into the country with a horse and cart—I thought him an honest man—I believe my superior officers have got nothing against me—I do not know whether they know that I am dealing in articles of this description—it is contrary to our regulations to do this—I believe I first began to deal in these articles on the day I sent in my resignation—I had dealt in articles for my own family before that time—I sent in my resignation a month last Wed
nesday—I cannot recollect how long it was before Good Friday.

Q. What other things did you take to Mrs. Edwards, besides these? A. An iron boiler, a pair of trowsers and a waistcoat, to see if she would buy them—I bought the iron boiler at Birmingham, ten years ago—the waistcoats I bought at Burlton's, the pawnbroker's, a few days before, and the trowsers in the New-cut—Mrs. Edwards is a fellmonger—on the 13th Herne was on duty somewhere in the Brixton-road—I do not do duty there myself—I gave in
formation directly I suspected the things were stolen—I inquired of my brother officer what Herne was locked up for—he said it was for something at North Brixton, and gave me a description of a few things which were stolen—I have been in the tailoring business before I came to London, at Thornbury, in Buckinghamshire.

ELIZABETH LAMBURN . On Thursday morning, the 13th of April, Herne came to my house, and asked if my husband was at home—I said, "Yes, in bed"—he said he wanted to see him, he had seen some things which he thought he could buy cheap, and he wished him to go and see them, they belonged to a poor man who was hard up—I called my husband twice, and he came down—Herne repeated the same words to him that he told me—they went out together—on Easter Monday he came again, and brought three pairs of shoes, a Petersham coat and cloak, and a copper tea-kettle, and left them—they remained there till Slack came, and my husband delivered them up, as soon as he had suspicions they were stolen.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Have you ever been in the way of dealing with various articles? A. Never—I have been married a long time—I live in James-street, Camberwell—not the same James-street that Herne lived in—we have the house to ourselves—I did not think it an extraordinary thing that a policeman should have such property as this.

MARY EDWARDS . I am the wife of Henry Edwards, and live in Baal
zephon-street, Long-lane, Bermondsey. I have seen Herne once—Lam
burn and he came to my house, and brought an iron boiler and a tea-kettle—Lamburn asked me to buy the kettle—I declined—he said he had got a candlestick—Herne was by at the time—I had bought the boiler of Mrs. Lamburn some time before—Hutchings lodged at my house at the time.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST? A. Did you buy any waistcoats? A. We had spoken to Lamburn about them—Herne came apparently to carry them—he did not appear to be bargaining or taking any interest in them—he asked what I thought of their going trafficking—he said to my mother, "What do you think of our concern?"—I had known Lamburn some time—we had lived together two years in one house, at Peckham—I had heard from Lamburn's wife, on Easter Monday, that Lamburn proposed that Herne and he should go about—I had heard Lamburn was going to leave the police.
JANE HUTCHINGS . I was lodging with Mrs. Edwards—I bought this brass candlestick of Lamburn for 1s., at his house at Peckham.

Cross-examined. Q. Had he many articles for sale? A. Yes, he showed me various articles, a coat and cloak, a copper tea-kettle, scales, and waist
coats.
THOMAS SLACK (police-constable P 3.) I produce some shoes and other

articles which I got at Lamburn's house—he was No. 128 in the same divi
sion as the prisoner.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Are you the superintendent over Herne? A. No, sergeant—he was not on duty in Addison-place North, Brixton-road, but on the next beat, but it nearly came to the place where the prosecutor lives—Smith did duty in that street—he is discharged—Herne lived at No. 39, James-street, and Rowland lived at No. 54, James-street.

MR. RYLAND. Q. Was Smith discharged in consequence of this bur
glary? A. Yes—Herne had the night duty, on Wednesday night, on the adjoining beat.

SAMPSON DARKIN CAMPBELL . I am an inspector of the P division. In consequence of information, on Sunday, the 30th of April, I apprehended Herne at the corner of James-street—on Tuesday, the 2nd of May, I went to No. 54, James-street, with Kendall—I had heard Rowland lived there-he was not at home—I had some conversation with his wife—he afterwards came in—I told him I had come to his house to make some inquiries relative to some property that had been left at his house by Herne the policeman-I read the list of them from this paper—(reads)—"One brown Petershars great coat, one brown cloak, one copper tea-kettle, one brass candlestick, a black velvet waistcoat, a copper scale, with dial, one side of pork, and three pairs of shoes"—he said, "These things were never brought here"—his wife was present, so as to hear that—I said, "You had better be on your guard, your wife has already admitted that the things were brought here"—she said, "You had better tell the truth"—he then said, "On the morning of the 13th of April, between two and three o'clock, I was in the road, near Mr. Myatt's garden, when Herne and Smith came up to me; Herne gave me a side of pork and half a ham, which I carried home; shortly after, while I was lacing my boots, Herne came in with the other things"—Kendall asked him how he was positive as to the day—he said because it was the day before Good Friday, market morning, and that was the reason he was out so early.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Did you find any of these articles at his house? A. No—I had previously communicated to his wife what I came for—I had got information from Lamburn, who was in our division—he is not discharged—he has been reported to the Commissioners—Herne was acting as a policeman at the time the robbery took place—Rowland's wife was very much alarmed—Rowland did not exhibit any agitation; and when Kendall asked him about the day, he gave every information—he seemed to fix my attention to that day, that I might make no mistake.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. This conversation with Row
land was relative to the things which were said to have been brought by Lam
burn? A. Yes—Rowland admitted that they were at his house—it was at Rowland's house that I had the conversation—Herne lives at No. 54, nearly opposite—his wife was not living with him at that time—the police are not allowed to trade at all, or to buy any articles but for their own use—as they had given notice to quit, I should not have reported about their buying a stock of goods, but in ordinary cases I should.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. You have been a long time acquainted with the neighbourhood where Rowland lives, and knew him? A. I have known him as a servant of Mr. Myatt—I never knew any thing against him before.
Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Nor against Herne? A. Not as to his honesty—Myatt is a large market-gardener—Rowland was his carter.

PETER KENDALL (police-sergeant P 1.) I went with Campbell, on the 2nd of May, to Rowland's house—I examined Mr. Bennett's premises last Sunday—the outside frame of the kitchen window had been cut, appa
rently with a knife, so as to admit an instrument to turn the button inside; and that being undone, the opening was large enough for a man to get in—I examined the dairy door, and a portion of the wood was cut where the bolt of the lock shuts, so as to admit an instrument to put the bolt back—I got this candlestick from Mr. Hutchings.

JOHN BENNETT
re-examined. Q. Did the kitchen window and dairy door remain in the state in which they were, on the morning after the robbery, till last Sunday? A. Yes.

SAMSON DARKIN CAMPBELL
re-examined. I was present when the pri
soners were examined before Mr. Trail—they were asked if they wished to say any thing, and cautioned in the usual way—what they said was taken down in writing—this is Mr. Trail's signature—(read)—"The prisoner Herne declines saying any thing at present. The prisoner Rowland says, 'On the Thursday before Good Friday Herne bought the things, and on the Thursday I had the meat in the lane from Herne.'"

HERNE—
GUILTY . Aged 27.—
Transported for Life.

ROWLAND—
NOT GUILTY .

1709.
CHARLES COOK was indicted
for stealing, on the 11th of May, 1 spoon, value 12s., the goods of
Richard Elworthy, his master.

RICHARD ELWORTHY . I am a cowkeeper, and live at Bermondsey. The prisoner was in my service. I missed a spoon about one o'clock on Thursday last—I had not seen it since the Monday—this it it—I have the fellow to it in my pocket.

GEORGE POOLE . I am a pawnbroker, and live in New Park-street. The prisoner came to my shop, and offered to pawn this spoon, on Thursday last—he asked 5s. for it—he said it was his own, and it appeared as if it had just been used—I stopped it—he had a horse and cart with him—the prose
cutor's name was on the cart.
Prisoner. I did not take it to the shop. Witness. I am certain it was him—he said he gave 6s. 6d. to a pawnbroker for it.

GUILTY .—
Confined Three Months.
ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, JUNE 12TH, 1843.
